Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
on.natgeo.com/instagram
animalplanet, wildlife_photography_india, natgeowild y 17 más siguen esta cuenta

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @jenguyton | Cyclone Freddy, which made landfall in Mozambique for the second time last Saturday, is shattering records for the longest lasting and most energetic storm. Freddy has killed dozens of people in Mozambique and Malawi.

Climate change intensifies such weather events the world over. These images are from another record-busting storm, Cyclone Idai. On March 15, 2019, it made landfall in Beira, Mozambique, and claimed more than 1,300 people, making it one of the deadliest storms on record in the Southern Hemisphere. Thousands were displaced when their homes collapsed or flooded; many lived in Gorongosa National Park’s adjacent buffer zone.

Park staff put their usual work on hold to respond to the crisis. Before the major aid agencies had organized relief, rangers began to fly food and supplies to communities that had been cut off by floodwaters from the outside world, their crops and food stores destroyed.

I made these images while riding along with relief teams in the park's buffer zone. Joana Vitor (above) went into labor in the midst of the cyclone. As her house fell around her, she gave birth, alone and unaided. Here, baby Teresa is three weeks old and healthy. Behind them, a park helicopter arrives with emergency supplies. In the other images: people await food distribution in the Bebedo community, and others bring food parcels home in a community called Machongo Barada.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 15, 2023. May be an image of 7 people, child and outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Eduard Florin Niga @eduardflorinnigaphotography | Ants are my absolute favorite subject to photograph. I find myself browsing endlessly through my galleries of ants, and I realize that I may sometimes forget the names of some of the species I imaged over the years, but I always remember how I felt when I created each photograph. Each time I relive a mixture of childlike curiosity, excitement, bewilderment, joy, and that secret feeling you get when you know you've experienced something very few may have.

What attracted me to ants in the first place was the discovery of how varied their "faces" are. The variation in color, size, shape, morphology, and texture is just extraordinary, and I'm convinced I will continue to be surprised by this for a very long time.

The process of imaging each of these tiny yet mighty beauties is hardly ever an easy one. Every "portrait" I create takes me a lot of time, patience (which I was told I lack), and hundreds and hundreds of carefully planned and expertly executed images that I then merge into the final frame I share with the big world. It involves countless sleepless nights, as I mainly work at night at the back of my house in a dimly lit, silent, vibration-free environment, an environment I imagine being very similar to an underground ants’ nest. Is it easy? No, not by any stretch of the imagination. But it is extremely rewarding, and the satisfaction I get from sharing these with the world and creating awareness out there is fANTastic. The only regret I have is not starting this adventure sooner.

Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 14, 2023. May be a closeup of nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @stephenwilkes | During a winter scouting trip in Alaska several years ago, I discovered a frozen mountaintop lake. Our helicopter was able to land on it. It was bitter cold, but a truly magical experience seeing untouched glacial ice on a brilliant blue-sky day. The ice displays an endless array of patterns, colors, and textures. This was a detail shot of the ice, which dramatically changed in appearance as a snow gust blew in. Suddenly the scene began to resemble a mountain shot from above, but it's an illusion. To see more from my travels near and far, follow me @stephenwilkes.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 14, 2023. May be a closeup of outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @richardbarnes | Since 2019 I've been photographing for a National Geographic story on the repatriation of objects from European and North American museums to the countries that originally created them. For many years now I've been involved in photography in and around museum collections across the globe. I'm interested in how nations or peoples define themselves through their collections and how those collections were obtained, curated, and put on display.

Colonial powers acquired (some would say stole) sacred objects and historical artifacts from African nations as well as from North American Indian tribes for the better part of the 19th and early 20th centuries. Recently, curators, museum directors, politicians, and others have advocated a return of these objects to their "rightful" owners, primarily in African nations. I've photographed in Cameroon, Nigeria, Benin, and Kenya, as well as in numerous European and North American museums where these objects have been housed for decades. It's a complex and nuanced story: In many instances it's unclear if the objects that ended up in European and American museums were legally obtained, "gifted," or stolen. In some cases—as with the thousands of Benin Bronzes, which were looted by the British in a punitive raid of 1897—it's clear, but in others it's open to interpretation and not so definitive as to how the objects found their way into European and North American collections.

National Geographic and writer Andrew Curry take on this important story and examine it from all sides in the March edition of the magazine. I am grateful to have been a part of it. Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 14, 2023. May be an image of 5 people and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @celestesloman | American textile artist Bisa Butler sits for a portrait at her studio in New Jersey. In celebration of Women's History Month, I photographed Butler—who created a new genre of portraiture in quilting—for National Geographic. #WomensHistoryMonth
ph_atributos: Photo shared by National Geographic on March 13, 2023 tagging @bisabutler. May be an image of 2 people and indoor.

ph_descripcion:
Read the full story at the link in bio.

Unlike the movie, the real-life cocaine bear didn't go on a coke-fueled rampage, but it did consume a fatal amount of cocaine left in the woods by smugglers.

Photograph of an American black bear eating dandelions by Barrett Hedges, Nat Geo Image Collection
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 13, 2023. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Yes, there was a real "Cocaine Bear." But the true story is no laughing matter.'.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | Evening falls over a canal in Amsterdam. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic. #MuhammedMuheisen #Amsterdam #Netherlands
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 13, 2023. May be an image of body of water.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @jasperdoest | An Anatolian leopard, an endangered species native to the Iranian plateau whose territory spans more than 40 square kilometers (15 sq mi), now inhabits a small zoo enclosure in Duhok, Iraq. This animal, with an estimated wild population of only a thousand, lost one of its hind legs after getting caught in a wolf trap placed by mountain shepherds trying to protect their herds.

Despite the IUCN’s recommendation that the leopard be relocated to a larger facility in Europe as part of a breeding program, the government has deemed it the property of Iraq, and the animal has been unable to receive the resources it needs for full rehabilitation. The leopard’s growl of distress speaks volumes—a heartbreaking reminder of the consequences of human intervention and the urgent need to protect the dwindling population of threatened species. Follow me @jasperdoest for more on the relationship between humankind and nature. #leopard #endangeredspecies #humananimalbond
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 12, 2023. May be an image of big cat.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @babaktafreshi | In 2009, on a peaceful starry night in a remote village in Iran's southeastern Sistan and Baluchestan Province, this group, well past their bedtime, was curious to see what I was doing out here in the dark—I photograph the night sky. I'm also originally from Iran. In the past few months, people in this province lost their lives while standing up for freedom against security forces that used snipers and warfare on unarmed protestors. Human rights agencies estimated that 70 children under the age of 18 have been killed in the nationwide protests that began in the wake of the death of Mahsa Amini. The UN Human Rights Council has launched an investigation into allegations around the deaths as well as the torture of protesters and missing persons.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 12, 2023. May be an image of 9 people, people standing and sky.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @paoloverzone | A team of geneticists headed by Yehia Gad collects DNA sampling from the mummy of an unidentified boy in the tomb of Pharaoh Amenhotep II. A pioneer in the DNA analysis of ancient mummies, Gad is studying samples from King Tutankhamun and his extended family, looking for clues to their ancestral links and genetic maladies. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories. Read the full article in the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 12, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @kiliiiyuyan | A young guanaco—also known as a chulengo—greets its mother while tasting the air with its lips withdrawn. A South American relative of the camel, guanacos gestate for an entire year, then stay with their mother for another. That two-year commitment to its chulengo is one of the longest in the animal world and is a mother’s gift of survival to its offspring. Follow me, @kiliiiyuyan, for more love between the human-animal worlds.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 12, 2023. May be an image of animal and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | Trekkers head back from a waterfall-soaked adventure inside Kahuzi-Biega National Park, located in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Named for its two extinct volcanoes, the park is home to a population of 250 protected eastern lowland gorillas—believed to be the last remaining. Gorilla trekking is the prime draw at the park; the area also hosts a chimpanzee habituation program at Lwiro Sanctuary as well as bird watching activities. The park is home to over 349 species, with 42 endemic to the region. Follow me at @michaelchristopherbrown for more stories from around the world.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 11, 2023. May be an image of 6 people, waterfall and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nadiashiracohen | When Phalla became a surrogate for a middle-class Chinese couple, she never imagined that the baby growing in her belly would be for keeps. Yet when the housing complex she lived in—run by the agency that placed her—was raided by police and she was arrested, along with 30 other surrogates, her life would change forever. Though there was no law on surrogacy in Cambodia, to discourage the practice it was treated as a form of human trafficking. The women were sentenced to raise, under supervision, the children they later bore. Phalla has come to love her daughter unconditionally as one of her own. For more on this story, please follow me @nadiashiracohen.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 11, 2023. May be an image of 1 person, standing, flower, tree and grass.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | Escaping horseflies, a male South American tapir (Tapirus terrestris) known as Gonzalito crosses the Tiputini River in the Ecuadorian Amazon. Hunters captured Gonzalito as a baby, and Ecuador’s Ministry of Environment rescued and released him when he was an adult. Over three years, I was able to observe him in the wild during my visits to the community of Mandari in the Amazon. Unfortunately, Gonzalito died last year, killed during the pandemic under unknown circumstances. Follow @javier_aznar_photography for more stories from the jungle. #tapir #amazon #rainforest
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 11, 2023. May be an image of animal and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Faustina Flores Carranza, 68, and Juan Astudillo Jesus, 65, sit in their solar-lit home in San Luis Acatlán, a town in Guerrero, Mexico. The couple of 50 years have seven children. Like many members of the Mextica Indigenous community, they live in rural areas outside the reach of electric grids. When I asked how solar has made a difference in their lives, Faustina answered, “For the first time, we are able to look at each other in the eyes in our moments of intimacy.” This photograph is part of Solar Portraits, a long-term project that addresses the lack of electricity access around the world and the positive impact that solar electricity systems are having in different communities. Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens. #solarportraits #solar #Mexico #solarpanels #solarpower
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 11, 2023. May be an image of 2 people.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @beverlyjoubert | There are plenty of hunting opportunities for a hungry lion in Botswana’s Okavango Delta … but finding them often involves a soggy trudge through the region’s famous swamplands. The lions here may have learned to navigate these inundated landscapes in search of prey, but venturing into the water is always a step outside of the comfort zone. With its sights set on a nearby lechwe–an antelope perfectly designed for the marshy life–this lion certainly has its work cut out. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert. #bigcats #bigcatsofinstagram
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 10, 2023. May be an image of big cat and nature.

Read the full story at the link in bio.

From gels and pills to implants, the contraceptive choices accessible to most men may soon expand beyond condoms and vasectomies.

Micrograph by D. Phillips, Science Photo Library
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 10, 2023. May be an image of text that says 'Male birth control is advancing. From pills to gels, here's how they work.'.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @andrea_frazzetta | Located in northern Ethiopia's Afar Triangle, the Danakil Depression is where three tectonic plates meet. This vast plain is the homeland of the Afar nomads, who live off extracting minerals, namely salt, in one of the most inhospitable places on Earth. Follow @andrea_frazzetta for more images and stories. #Africa #Ethiopia #Danakil
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 10, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @andrea_frazzetta | Located in northern Ethiopia's Afar Triangle, the Danakil Depression is where three tectonic plates meet. Follow @andrea_frazzetta for more images and stories. #Africa #Ethiopia #Danakil
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 10, 2023. May be an image of 1 person, standing, fire and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @yagazieemezi | Two members of Mavula Sape strike a pose in the trunk of an old taxi in their neighborhood of Mikalu in Brazzaville, Congo. Even without a camera pointed at them, the sapeuses maintain fashionable stances, almost as if they are silently competing with each other. Their individual personas are defined by their unique style and flair, and some are known by their clothing colors, walks, hairstyles, and even exaggerated facial expressions. Mavula Sape is part of SAPE (Société des Ambianceurs et des Personnes Élégantes, or Society of Tastemakers and Elegant People), a subculture that can be traced back to the 1920s, when young men, as a form of protest against French-colonial powers, adopted the clothing of their “masters” and created their own unique styles. While the men, the sapeurs, have gained international recognition over the years with their dapper and colorful suits, the women (sapeuses) were not as well-known despite having embraced the culture for decades. Women supporting women—whether enjoying a spectacle of expression or engaging in local services provided by women—foster independence of spirit and self. | Global #logistics brand @dhl_global is supporting the SheTrades Program, amplifying cultural and social movements across the globe and encouraging female entrepreneurs to play a bigger role in society and the economy. Read more at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 09, 2023. May be an image of 2 people, suit and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @brianskerry | Beluga whales swim in shallow water in the Canadian Arctic. They come to an estuary in summertime to rest and play. The whales also rub their bodies on the gravel bottom, using it like a natural loofah to exfoliate their skin. To read the full story on the hidden world of whale culture, go to the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 09, 2023. May be an image of outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @ismailferdous | Sugar Loaf Dam is a concrete gravity dam just outside of Leadville, Colorado. Completed in the 1960s, the dam was designed to divert water for irrigation, hydroelectric power generation, and municipal and industrial water supply across the eastern slope of the Rocky Mountains. The dam's name comes from Sugarloaf Mountain, which can be seen from the reservoir it created, known as Turquoise Lake, which is also a popular destination for fishing, boating, and other recreational activities. For more stories and pictures follow @ismailferdous.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 09, 2023. May be an image of 2 people and nature.

ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 09, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @amivitale | In northern Kenya, Naitemu Letur pushes a jug of water back to her manyatta, or settlement. Worldwide, women and girls spend an estimated 200 million hours daily collecting water, according to UNICEF. This one task robs them of their time and potential. They’re not able to develop their own skills because they must spend all of their free time collecting water. On this International Women’s Day, let’s honor all the accomplishments of women and work toward a world where every woman has the chance to realize her full potential. Follow @amivitale for more stories of our interconnected world. #InternationalWomensDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 08, 2023. May be an image of 1 person, standing and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @erintrieb | On International Women’s Day, I think of the incredible women I’ve met all over the world. Among them are the Kurdish Iraqi college students I photographed in 2015 in the Kurdistan region of northern Iraq; they wouldn’t quit playing basketball despite war raging all around them. With the Islamic State attacking and seizing large swaths of land in Iraq, people were fleeing for their lives. It was a dangerous time for women—especially for Christians, Yazidis, and Kurds—who were frequently kidnapped and killed by insurgents. The young women who attended the American University of Iraq in Sulaymaniyah not only kept going to school, but they also refused to give up the sport. Many of them are now in their 30s and have children of their own. It was heartening to spend time with them nearly a decade ago, on and off the court, as they figured out who they wanted to be and what they stood for. For more stories of women from around the world, follow @erintrieb. #InternationalWomensDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 08, 2023. May be an image of 10 people, people standing, footwear and indoor.

The young women who attended the American University of Iraq in Sulaymaniyah not only kept going to school, but they also refused to give up the sport. Many of them are now in their 30s and have children of their own. It was heartening to spend time with them nearly a decade ago, on and off the court, as they figured out who they wanted to be and what they stood for. For more stories of women from around the world, follow @erintrieb. #InternationalWomensDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 08, 2023. May be an image of 6 people and people sitting.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @erintrieb | On International Women’s Day, I think of the incredible women I’ve met all over the world. Among them are the Kurdish Iraqi college students I photographed in 2015 in the Kurdistan region of northern Iraq; they wouldn’t quit playing basketball despite war raging all around them. With the Islamic State attacking and seizing large swaths of land in Iraq, people were fleeing for their lives. It was a dangerous time for women—especially for Christians, Yazidis, and Kurds—who were frequently kidnapped and killed by insurgents. The young women who attended the American University of Iraq in Sulaymaniyah not only kept going to school, but they also refused to give up the sport. Many of them are now in their 30s and have children of their own. It was heartening to spend time with them nearly a decade ago, on and off the court, as they figured out who they wanted to be and what they stood for. For more stories of women from around the world, follow @erintrieb. #InternationalWomensDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 08, 2023. May be an image of 5 people, people playing sports and people standing.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @luisadorr | Teffy is a member of the ImillaSkate collective, whose members wear traditional pollera skirts and hats, in Cochabamba, Bolivia. For her, skateboarding is not only a sport, it's a lifestyle.

"Even though the discrimination against Indigenous people in Bolívia is huge, I believe that wearing a pollera to skateboard identifies myself with my roots," she says. It's empowering for the group, which aspires to attract more women to the sport and tackle stereotypes.

Teffy stands on the city's San Pedro hill. "When you look at this view," she says, "you see that nature thrives here and that not all is lost because of technological developments and population growth—and the most important of all, I'm proud of being K'ochala."

To read more about the women, go to the link in bio. #InternationalWomensDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 08, 2023. May be an image of 1 person, standing and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | A five-month-old camel, Baarud playfully tugs at Aadar Mohamed's hijab, in a coastal village in Somaliland. Baarud, which means "tough" in Somali, was given the name because its mother nearly died in a drought while it was in utero. To save her, Aadara divided her own meager rations and nursed the camel back to life. As the region once again endures a horrific drought–the worst in recorded history–it feels vital to reflect on the intimate connection among people, their animals, and the land. Read about the millions of migrant women like Aadara, whose lives have been upended by climate change, at the link in bio. To see more of my work on humanity, please follow @nicholesobecki. #InternationalWomensDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 08, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Michael Yamashita @yamashitaphoto | With more than 650 mines, Shanxi Province in northern China is the country’s top producer of coal, with the Inner Mongolia region a close second. China is also the world’s largest consumer of coal and such dependence has its costs, namely the environmental impacts of rising greenhouse gas emissions. In September 2020, President Xi Jinping announced that China would become carbon neutral by 2060. Smaller mines were shut down and others consolidated into fewer but larger power companies, all with an eye toward shifting to wind- and solar-powered electricity. But change is hard. Because of a power crunch, China has had to ramp up coal production and, according to a recent report by the Center for Research on Energy and Clean Air and the Global Energy Monitor, has approved construction permits for new power plants at the rate of two a week in 2022. #coalmines #energy
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 07, 2023. May be an image of 2 people and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @jimmychin | Towering above all else, Antarctica's Ulvetanna, aka the Wolf’s Fang, both inspires and intimidates. Taller than El Cap—Yosemite National Park's wall of rock—it's a complex mountain with a history of epic ascents and numerous failed attempts. Every aspect of the mountain can hold your gaze for hours as you try to decipher the maze of ridges and lines and the type of climbing required to navigate it all.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 07, 2023. May be an image of mountain and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @jimmychin | Towering above all else, Antarctica's Ulvetanna, aka the Wolf’s Fang, both inspires and intimidates. ph_descripcion:
Photo by @tasneemalsultan | With the recent earthquakes, my thoughts turned again to the plight of Syrian refugees and how these events exacerbate their tenuous situation. This photo of a Syrian refugee was taken in Amman, Jordan, in 2016.

"I've stopped going to school for a few months now. I want to keep attending but the boys here harass me, asking me to sell myself since I'm a Syrian girl. They keep saying that pretty Syrian girls get a lot of money." I was walking with the 14-year-old through a graveyard. "We were never harassed back home," she continued. "But Syria is gone."

I saw so much devastation in the young eyes of these beautiful souls. I had never witnessed such love for a nation or land. A 10- year-old wrote a poem, a 15-year-old made a collage, and a 7-year-old created a photo essay, all focused on the loss of their beloved Syria, a place now further traumatized and forgotten.

Was Syria ideal? Or do we miss only what we can't ever get back? As we exchanged hugs and tears, I realized the strongest souls are the ones that keep smiling. She adds: "It's not being in denial; being positive is a must."
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 07, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Tomas van Houtryve @tomasvh | Early on a cold winter morning in Paris, hundreds of paddle boarders on the Seine River pass next to Notre Dame Cathedral. The interior of Notre Dame has been closed to the public since a devastating fire in April 2019, but it's scheduled to reopen at the end of 2024. For more photos and stories about Notre Dame, follow @tomasvh.
#notredamedeparis
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 07, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @sofia_jaramillo5 | Shepherd Adriel Alvarado, from Peru, tracks his sheep near Hailey, Idaho. Each October, Hailey and the nearby town of Ketchum host the Trailing of the Sheep Festival, an agricultural fair that draws more than 25,000 people and over 3,000 sheep.

Sheepherding is tied to Basque settlers who brought their skills and traditions to Idaho. An estimated 15,000 people who are of Basque heritage live in the state, which teems with Basque culture.

For more on this story, see the link in bio and follow @sofia_jaramillo5. #sheep #idaho #travel
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 06, 2023. May be an image of outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Read the full story at the link in bio.

For children in wealthier nations, 80 will be the new 60. That means a life filled with day-to-day technological advances—and a new way of thinking about school, work, and retirement.

Photograph by Melanie Wenger, National Geographic
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 06, 2023. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'Today's newborns will likely live to 100. What will their lives be like?'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @paoloverzone | The mummy known as KV21B undergoes a CT scan at the Egyptian Museum in Cairo. This and another mummy, KV21A, were found in the KV21 tomb located in the Valley of the Kings. Discovered by Italian archaeologist and explorer Giovanni Belzoni in 1817, the tomb was later re-excavated by American archaeologist Donald P. Ryan in the 1980s. Some Egyptologists think KV21A and KV21B might be 18th dynasty queens, so further analysis of DNA samples and CT scans are being conducted to determine the mummies’ origins and family tree. Egyptian archaeologists such as Zahi Hawass consider KV21B a candidate for the body of Nefertiti. Read more about Egyptian-led projects that will shed light on the country’s rich past, including the Grand Egyptian Museum, at the link in bio. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 06, 2023. May be an image of indoor.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | How small we appear against such monuments of history. At the ancient city of Petra, in Jordan, the towering edifice of Al Khazneh (the Treasury) is one of many facades carved into the mountains. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic. #MuhammedMuheisen #Jordan #الاردن #Petra
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 06, 2023. May be an image of outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renaeffendiphoto | Wedged among the Mediterranean Sea, Syria, and Israel, Lebanon has seen a brutal collapse of its vibrant liberal haven in the Middle East. The country’s deterioration has been rapid and painful. A severe economic crisis in 2019 caused more than half the population of a once middle-income nation to plunge into poverty within the span of a year or so. The arrival of COVID-19 worsened already desperate conditions. The Lebanese are a study in resilience but also of multigenerational trauma. In the March issue, an essay from Lebanese writer Rania Abouzeid examines the country’s breakdown and how the 2020 Beirut port explosion was its gravest manifestation. From the rich and aristocratic to the low income, all Lebanese are grappling with a confluence of crises—financial, security, and political.

(1) A group of women explores a fort known as the Sea Castle, built in the 13th century by the Crusaders, on the coastline of Sidon, Lebanon’s third largest city. Archaeological sites are found all along the ancient land’s shore.

(2) On August 4, 2020, an explosion at a Port of Beirut warehouse storing ammonium nitrate killed at least 218 people, injured thousands, and destroyed more than 85,000 properties. These grain silos absorbed some of the blast’s impact, shielding part of the capital from widespread damage.

(3) Ralph Mellehe’s family weeps over his coffin. Mellehe was part of a 10-person firefighting team dispatched to put out the blaze.

(4) In Batroun, modern restaurants and clubs exist alongside ancient ruins and historic churches.

(5) Hady Fowal, 12, joined a group of men who set up a roadblock of burning tires in March 2021 on the main highway to Tripoli as a protest of Lebanon’s deteriorating economic conditions.

(6) Lebanese relax in seawater pools at a beach resort in Chekka on the northern coast in September 2019. A month later, the nation’s economy crumbled.

Read the full story in the link in bio. #lebanon #beirut #crisis
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 05, 2023. May be an image of 4 people, people standing and outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @gerdludwig | Ethereal and mysterious, fog envelops the old graveyard in Amoeneburg, a village rich in history and tradition in Hesse, Germany. Excavations in the area suggest that the region may have been settled during the New Stone Age.

Amidst the mist, dedicated relatives tend to the graves of their loved ones, their silhouettes barely visible against the wooden crosses. Their diligent efforts are a testament to the enduring bond between the living and the deceased, and the sun struggling to break through the fog is a symbol of hope and renewal in this timeless place.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 05, 2023. May be an image of 2 people and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | Rangers at Virunga National Park headquarters in Rumangabo, Democratic Republic of the Congo, train two bloodhounds and a spaniel, both breeds essential in the battle to prevent poaching inside the park. In the right conditions, bloodhounds can trace a human scent up to ten kilometers (6 mi) and even for several days afterward. The spaniels are primarily used to trace weapons and ivory. Their caretakers are among the 700+ Virunga rangers, heroes risking their lives to protect endangered animals, such as the several hundred mountain gorillas who live there, in the name of conservation. More than 200 rangers have been killed in the line of duty.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 05, 2023. May be an image of ‎3 people, dog, outdoors and ‎text that says '‎محی‎'‎‎.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @martinschoeller | In 2022 I began a series photographing and sharing the experiences of Native peoples in America. The portraits were taken at the Gathering of Nations, the largest powwow in North America. This is Jessica R. Bojorquez of California's La Jolla Band of Luiseño Indians:

“I learned later on in life that I was Native. My parents didn’t tell us, because back in the day—my grandparents’ generation—it was even worse to be Native than it was to be Black in Southern California. Natives weren't allowed in town; we had bounties on our heads. A lot of Natives transferred over to the Spanish side [Mexico]. They went across the border and portrayed themselves as Mexicans—that way they could go into town and buy things and not be killed, in other words."

For more portraits and stories in this series, follow me @martinschoeller.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 04, 2023. May be a closeup of 1 person.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @babaktafreshi | I have peaceful memories of this 2010 evening in a Kurdish village in Iran, including a group of curious children following me around while I photographed the cultural landscape of Hawraman, a World Heritage site.

Today Kurdish cities are the beating heart of protests against the Islamic Republic of Iran and its brutal treatment toward unarmed protesters. The uprising was triggered last September by the death of Mahsa Amini, a Kurdish woman who died in police custody. Protesters have embraced the slogan “Woman, Life, Freedom,” which has roots in female militias fighting against ISIS. Kurds are an ethnic group whose culture is thousands of years old; their influence can be found in Persian music, language, and traditions. They are native to the Zagros Mountains, which span Iran, Iraq, and Turkey. Most of the estimated 40 million Kurds worldwide reside in these three countries, as well as Syria. #iranprotests #MahsaAmini #womanlifefreedom
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 04, 2023. May be an image of mountain and sky.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @bertiegregory | Despite being one of the most numerous fish groups on the planet, lantern fish are rarely seen—and thus little is known about them. They undertake a daily vertical migration: they come to the surface at night, returning to the deep during the day. Occasionally, for reasons we don’t understand, they get caught at the surface and a feeding frenzy develops. Photographed for my new show, now streaming on @disneyplus. #EpicAdventuresWithBertieGregory
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 04, 2023. May be an image of food.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @jasperdoest | Sometimes you come across people who brighten your world. Mert Akkök is one of those. We came across him as Floortje Dessing and I traveled overland from Amsterdam to Nepal in search of human-animal relationship stories.

Akkök plays the flute for his beloved animals in his living room, a place of solace and comfort for the 70+ strays he has welcomed and rescued on his farm just south of Istanbul. He joined a growing number of city dwellers moving to the countryside, where he cares for his four-legged friends. His blind horse, Reyhan, is drawn to the mellow sounds of the music and has even damaged his saxophone in her enthusiasm.

Through it all, Akkök's door remains open, providing his furry family with a safe haven. “We enjoy each other's company,” he says. “They're like my kids now, and I would only give them to decent and good people who can take very good care of them.”

Follow me @jasperdoest for more on the relationship between humankind and nature. #compassion #humananimalbond
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 04, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and indoor.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | This adorable critter is a baby American badger photographed at Nebraska's @newildliferehab. In the wild this little one would belong to a litter, born in early spring. Blind at birth and almost completely helpless, baby badgers are nursed by mom until they are two to three months old. Despite their vulnerable state, youngsters may emerge from the den as early as five weeks old, but won’t fully venture out on their own until the six-month mark. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #badger #baby #animal #wildlife #photography #PhotoArk #WorldWildlifeDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 03, 2023. May be an image of indoor.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @beverlyjoubert | They're alert and watchful even during a thirst-quenching stopover at a rainwater pan in Botswana’s Okavango Delta. Though lions don’t need to drink every day—they can rely on the blood of their prey for a good portion of their moisture requirements—a convenient water source in the heat of the day is not to be passed up. I've witnessed so many fierce and violent facets of lion life, making a peaceful moment of rest and refreshment soothing to observe. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert. #lions #bigcats #bigcatconservation #WorldWildlifeDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 03, 2023. May be an image of big cat and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @brianskerry | A sperm whale calf swims beneath her mother in the eastern Caribbean Sea. Sperm whale families are matrilineal and led by the older, wiser females of the group. For the full story on whale culture, see the link in bio. #WorldWildlifeDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 03, 2023. May be an image of outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Javier Aznar @javier_aznar_photography | This portrait of a chachi tree frog (Boana picturata) was photographed in the Ecuadorian Chocó. Although the species is common in some areas, there is little data about it. A recent study that called the frog "an underexplored source of bioactive peptides" found three new antimicrobial peptide families in the skin secretions of the frog—a reminder that we must protect its habitat. As we bring many animals to extinction, we are destroying opportunities to find cures for diseases such as cancer and to discover new antibiotics for multiresistant bacteria among other substances.

Thanks to nonprofits such as @fundacion.jocotoco, this region of Ecuador and the species that inhabit it have a chance to survive. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to discover some of the animals in the rainforests of South America. #ecuador #frog #animals #wildebeest
#WorldWildlifeDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 03, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @chrisburkard | What does it take to surf in the Aleutian Islands? Months—even years—of planning. Countless late nights pouring over maps and swell charts trying to forecast waves that we'd only heard about from rumors. The extreme weather coming off the Bering Sea kept us slightly nervous as we waited for our window to fly in, hoping to catch the swell of a lifetime. The conditions lined up, the sky opened, and we couldn't believe the intersection of remote, snowy volcanoes and a perfect swell … truly an unforgettable experience.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 02, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @acacia.johnson | The port of Nome, Alaska, extends into the Bering Sea, and the loss of sea ice due to climate change could soon turn it into a major transport hub as the Arctic Ocean becomes increasingly navigable by ship. A planned expansion would make Nome the first deep-draft port (able to handle large ships) in the U.S. Arctic region. Follow me @acacia.johnson for more stories from Alaska and beyond. #alaska #nome #arctic #climatechange #seaiceloss
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 02, 2023. May be an image of ocean, nature and sky.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @moisessaman | Tiebele, a village in southern Burkina Faso, has some of the best preserved remaining examples of traditional painted Burkinabe architecture.

Crafted from mud and designed to allow for ventilation, the houses are then finished with coats of decorative paint that protect the dwellings from the rain. Despite the local king’s determination to preserve traditional ways of home construction, most locals have moved outside the royal court, or compound, in order to be able to build with concrete or in other nontraditional ways. There is a popular perception that concrete equates to modernity and that earth bricks are a symbol of poverty and backwardness. In addition, some local Christian and Muslim clerics see traditional architecture as an extension of animist beliefs, so they advise residents against living in mud-brick homes after they have converted to Christianity or Islam. NGOs and community elders are pushing back, hoping that cultural and ethnic identity will persuade some families to reembrace their cultural architecture tradition. Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 02, 2023. May be an image of outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio | In the predawn light of the Colorado Plateau, Lake Powell and its “bathtub ring” glow. This white line of mineral deposits has been left by the reservoir’s shrinking water levels—the result of a 22-year drought that has stretched water resources to their limits across the American West. Follow @elliotstudio as I continue to explore stories surrounding the Colorado River Basin.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 01, 2023. May be an image of body of water and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @dina_litovsky | Mexico City is one of my favorite cities in the world. I love exploring its streets and numerous parks, plazas, and markets, which offer vignettes and glimpses into the lives of people living in the capital. For more images, follow me @dina_litovsky.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 01, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and indoor.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @katieorlinsky | I captured the northern lights, also known as aurora borealis, on a February night in Canada's Yukon Territory in 2014. This incredible yet common phenomenon takes place near the magnetic poles, the result of collisions between electrically charged particles from the sun that enter Earth's atmosphere. It was the first time I saw the lights. Since then I've continued to work in the Arctic, but I still remember this night as the most spectacular display I've seen.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on March 01, 2023. May be an image of nature and sky.

It’s not just dogs: Even worms and ants can be trained to detect markers of illness, from COVID to tuberculosis.

Photograph by Johner Images, Getty Images
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 28, 2023. May be an image of dog and text that says 'What does cancer cancer smell like? Dogs aren't the only animals that can sniff sniff it out.'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | Who knew two rodents could be so cute? But these Mongolian gerbils are also what we call “desert tough”—they've learned how to survive even under the most extreme circumstances. In the semideserts and steppes of Mongolia, this species developed long legs for jumping and running away from predators; teeth to deal with hard seeds and plant matter; and water conservation techniques that allow them to survive in an unpredictable climate. Photo taken @gladysporterzoo in Brownsville, Texas. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #animals #wildlife #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 28, 2023. May be an image of rat.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @krisgraves | Behind-the-scenes preparations for the Disney Festival of Fantasy Parade, performed twice a day, begins just beyond visitor access at the Magic Kingdom Park. The parade’s route takes you past the iconic Cinderella Castle, which is currently decorated for the Walt Disney World Resort 50th Anniversary celebration. Readying for the massive production spreads even farther to the costuming facility, where many of the costumes for Walt Disney World Resort are made. The undisclosed location houses more costumes than I've ever seen in my life and is full of color. Some of the costumes worn by performers now include 3D-printed elements.

I was given the opportunity to capture life from behind the scenes at Walt Disney World Resort. Stay tuned for more of what makes Disney possible in the coming weeks and months. The Walt Disney Company is majority owner of National Geographic Partners. @WaltDisneyWorld @DisneyParks @natgeointhefield #DisneyWorld50
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 28, 2023. May be an image of 2 people and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @Jimmychin | From the archives, a few pictures from climber Dave Hahn's first foray in California's Yosemite National Park. He had climbed Everest 11 times, and Conrad Anker (leading in the first shot), Ivo Ninov, and I decided it was time for him to climb the other Big E—El Capitan. Dave might look a bit freaked out in photo two, but I’m pretty sure he had a good time in the end... I don’t think he was expecting one of the longer, steeper routes on El Cap. Classic sandbag.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 28, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renan_ozturk | A National Geographic team has made the first ascent of Mount Michael, an isolated active volcano in the South Sandwich Islands. Hampered by the region’s notorious winds and fickle weather, the expedition endured an 1,100-nautical-mile Atlantic Ocean passage followed by a glaciated mountain climb to get the first glimpse inside the summit's crater.

In these images: The volcano rises more than 3,000 feet (900 m).

The Australis, a 75-foot steel-hulled vessel, supported the team throughout the monthlong expedition. Guide Carla Perez looks out from its bow. Traveling against the prevailing winds, the return journey from Saunders Island lasted nearly two weeks.

The base camp’s tenuous perch on Saunders Island. Keeping tents properly tethered required hours of work each day.

The team steals a quick rest 300 feet below the summit during the ascent. The combination of humidity and wind caused rime, or bits of granular ice, to quickly form on clothing and equipment, making hypothermia a constant risk.

As gusts pummel her tent, volcanologist Emma Nicholson carefully melts each snow sample and adds a chemical agent to preserve the composition for study back home in the lab.

Unloading equipment on the beach at Saunders Island, home to an array of wildlife including chinstrap penguins, elephant seals, and giant albatross.

Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 27, 2023. May be an image of body of water and nature.

The reserve belongs to Al Ma’wa for Nature and Wildlife, part of the Princess Alia Foundation that provides emergency medical treatment, rehabilitation, and rehoming for animals. ph_descripcion:
Photo by Robin Hammond @hammond_robin | “I had to flee Uganda, because my life was in danger,” says Tasha, a transgender woman. She went to Kenya, hoping she’d find safety and acceptance. She quickly came to realize that transphobia was a real threat there too. “I only move out if it’s really important—very, very important—because I’m scared for my life.” Tasha posed for my long-term project, Where Love Is Illegal. She appears on the cover of my new book of the same name. You can see her story and many others at @whereloveisillegal.

This portrait was photographed using a large-format camera on instant film.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 27, 2023. May be a closeup of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @richardbarnes | I have been photographing a National Geographic story on repatriation for the past 3 years. Repatriation concerns the return of objects mostly from European and American museums to the countries or peoples that originally produced them. Some of the artifacts were given under duress, and others were looted outright, but still others, such as the Nefertiti bust, now in the Neues Museum in Berlin, may have been obtained legally. It's no secret that colonial powers were rapacious in the theft of objects sacred to the people who created them—from the Benin Bronzes looted in a British raid in 1897 to the Mandu Yenu throne, whose return the Bamun kings in Cameroon have been seeking for decades. It's a complicated and nuanced debate: Some former colonial powers, along with museums including the Smithsonian Institution, embrace return or transfer of control, and others justify their position by claiming that many of the objects in their collections would never have been preserved if it were not for a globe-trotting curator or colonial overlord who recognized their value and saved them from neglect or ruin. Nonetheless, I have witnessed a sea change since I started this project, with many museum directors, curators, and concerned government officials advocating for return in as conscientious and equitable a way as possible. It's never too late. Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 26, 2023. May be an image of 3 people and indoor.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @paoloverzone | A member of the conservation team at the temple of Amenhotep III, in Luxor, Egypt, uses air pressure to clean an alabaster statue. The mortuary temple was Thebes’s largest funeral complex. Only parts of its design remain, including the Colossi of Memnon, two large stone statues measuring nearly 60 feet (18 m) in height. A team of German-Egyptian researchers led by archaeologist Hourig Sourouzian has been digging at this incredible site for years. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 26, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @nadiashiracohen | Eight months ago, I seemingly released effortlessly the dock lines of our 50-foot catamaran, Takaroa ("sea god" in Maori), from its berth just outside of Rome. As we set off to circumnavigate the globe for three years, I knew nothing about sailing—only that boats made me queasy. Now my husband (an experienced sailor) and I trade off two-hour night watches on long passages. Nights blur into days—days we tend to lose track of, along with time zones. We homeschool our two children, Rafael and Olivia, although books seem futile compared to the experience of living in symbiosis with nature. After years of realizing carefully researched stories, my camera is now turned both inward and outward, dictated by the course of our exploration.

In August we stopped over at Mindelo, Cape Verde (above), where a tugboat stranded during rough weather in 2011 has been slowly sinking into the bay. It's costly to dispose of wrecks, so abandoned boats both small and large litter the islands of Cape Verde.

In January, near Port Williams, Chile, we rescued a baby duck that seemed lost. We scooped it up, offering water and bread. When it had built up its strength and began quacking, we set it out on the deck so that its mother might hear it. Sure enough, shortly thereafter, she passed by and the family was reunited.

In November, while docked at Mar del Plata, Argentina, Rafael looks out at a sea lion from his bedroom hatch.

In Punta del Este, Uruguay, a bird and a sea lion near a fish market await scraps.

In Barra Grande, Brazil, on October 3, Olivia roasts marshmallows at a beach in Bahia reachable only by boat—and therefore deserted.

In Patagonia, Argentina, Perito Moreno, one of the few advancing glaciers in the world, constantly calves ice. On a December morning, we witnessed several spectacular chunks fall into the water, followed by loud cracking noises and reverberating waves.

To follow my trip, go to @nadiashiracohen.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 26, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Javier Aznar @javier_aznar_photography | Did you know that some spiders take care of their eggs and babies, and some even transport the babies on their backs?
Spider egg sacs are multilayered and complex structures that physically protect the eggs and hatchlings against predators and parasitoids, as well as changing temperatures. Here you can see some examples that I photographed in the Ecuadorian Amazon.

Suspended by a thread of silk, a thorned heart orb weaver spider (Micrathena clypeata) builds her egg case in the Amazon rainforest near Tena, Ecuador.

A female orb weaver spider (Rubrepeira rubronigra) takes care of an egg sac among the vegetation near Tena, Ecuador.

A female orb weaver spider (Micrathena kirbyi) constructs an egg sac over a leaf in Yasuní, Ecuador.

Find more about these mesmerizing animals in the March issue of the magazine and at the link in bio.

ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 25, 2023. May be a closeup of nature.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Javier Aznar @javier_aznar_photography | Did you know that some spiders take care of their eggs and babies, and some even transport the babies on their backs?
Spider egg sacs are multilayered and complex structures that physically protect the eggs and hatchlings against predators and parasitoids, as well as changing temperatures. Here you can see some examples that I photographed in the Ecuadorian Amazon.

Suspended by a thread of silk, a thorned heart orb weaver spider (Micrathena clypeata) builds her egg case in the Amazon rainforest near Tena, Ecuador.

A female orb weaver spider (Rubrepeira rubronigra) takes care of an egg sac among the vegetation near Tena, Ecuador.

A female orb weaver spider (Micrathena kirbyi) constructs an egg sac over a leaf in Yasuní, Ecuador.

Find more about these mesmerizing animals in the March issue of the magazine and at the link in bio.

Follow @javier_aznar_photography to learn more about spiders and other small creatures. #spiders #mother #eggs #orbweaver
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 25, 2023. May be an image of nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder | A view over the coastline of Mahé, the largest island in the Seychelles. To boost the archipelago's resilience in the face of climate change and what's known as a blue economy—a sustainable living from the sea—the Seychelles exchanged its mounting national debt for dedicated ocean protection. In the “debt for nature” swap, the Nature Conservancy, a U.S. nonprofit, took on the debt in exchange for protection of its ocean areas. The initial pledge included creating 13 marine protected areas.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 25, 2023. May be an image of coast, ocean and nature.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @kholoodeid | While the majority of my professional and personal work has revolved around humans, dogs bring the joy, levity, and inspiration that makes me complete.

Oddly enough, I grew up terrified of dogs. Now I can hardly remember my life before adopting Professor, the ridiculous Westie mix in these photos. She's a hilarious and sweet girl I took home on my first day of grad school and has been my constant companion ever since.

I try to use photography as a way not only to understand our world but also as a form of healing for those I encounter. Now I'm using it as a form of healing for myself by incorporating joy and levity in my life on a more regular basis. In awe of these magnificent creatures, I aim to capture a glimpse of their amazingly unique personalities. Dogs featured in this post: Sora, Professor, Bosco, and Ryder.

Follow along at @wetnosepawject for more portraits, outtakes, and shenanigans.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 25, 2023. May be an image of dog and indoor.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Daniella Zalcman @dzalcman | A view from the Reunification Express, a 1,726-kilometer-long (1,072 mi) train route connecting the Vietnamese cities of Hanoi in the north to Ho Chi Minh City in the south. While the infrastructure has existed since the 1930s, decades of conflict caused widespread damage to the railway line, and it took a massive government effort after the Vietnam War ended in 1975 to render the line operational. Today, it takes about 30 hours to travel the route from end to end.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 25, 2023. May be an image of outdoors and temple.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | A Sudanese family from Karima tours the nearby tombs of El Kurru, where some of the earliest Kushite kings and queens were buried in the eighth century B.C. Just as many Europeans look to ancient Greece symbolically, many Africans are inspired by one of that continent's earliest civilizations, the kingdom of Kush. The Kushites erected mighty temples and tombs and some 255 pyramids—more than twice the number Egypt constructed next door. Read the full story at the link in bio. To see more of my work on the interdependence of humans and nature, please follow @nicholesobecki.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 24, 2023. May be an image of 8 people, people standing and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Reuben Wu @reuben | An enormous boulder outcrop in Bolivia's Eduardo Avaroa Andean Fauna National Reserve is illuminated by a light-carrying drone during a long exposure. Located in the Altiplano, the dunes and rocks of the Siloli Desert have been eroded by wind-blown sand over millennia. For more photos and stories, follow me @reuben.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 24, 2023. May be an image of sky and text.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @brianskerry | A curious gray seal swims right up to my camera in the waters of the Gulf of Maine. Gray seal populations throughout New England were decimated after centuries of hunting, but their numbers have rebounded substantially since the U.S. Marine Mammal Protection Act was passed in 1972. This image is from my upcoming story in @natgeo.
#Gulf of Maine
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 24, 2023. May be an image of body of water.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @moisessaman | Maxim Kiemdrebeojo, 17, has been living at an orphanage in Kougoudouli, Burkina Faso, since 2009. The building, made with laterite brick, was designed by Francis Kere, a Burkina Faso-born architect and globally renowned advocate of ecosensitive architecture. Some of the children housed at the orphanage are from communities displaced by conflict in the north and east of the country, while others have been given up by their desperate parents for economic reasons. Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 23, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and brick wall.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @martinschoeller | In 2022 I began a series photographing and sharing the experiences of Native peoples in America. The portraits were taken at Albuquerque's Gathering of Nations, the largest powwow in North America. This is Percy Edwards, from the Colville Confederated Tribe:

"My whole family lives on the reservation. My brother has danced all his life; my mom was a shaman, a medicine woman. In '03 my brother comes to me and says, 'Fill out this paperwork for eagle feathers.’ I am going, ‘what?’ I had shunned the Native life; I was a businessman living in faraway California. I had been the CEO of two companies, but still I gave the order and sent it to the fish and game department in Colorado. Three years later, a big box showed up with dry ice and I pulled out a frozen bald eagle.

So I started plucking the feathers and at night I start dreaming of dancing with the Old Ones. One morning I woke up, I saw face paint on me and a badger on my head. I turned to my wife and said, 'I want to start dancing.'"

Edwards's passage refers to the ability of Native Americans to apply to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service for access to eagle carcasses, parts, and feathers, which are used for ceremonial or religious purposes.

Thank you Percy Edwards for your words and time. For more portraits and stories in this series, follow me @martinschoeller.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 23, 2023. May be an image of one or more people, big cat and text that says 'CLO'.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @luisadorr | Belén is the youngest member of ImillaSkate, a women's skateboarding group in Cochabamba, Bolivia.

A physiotherapy student, Belén would like to match her career choice to her passion. She started skateboarding 4 years ago because she was amazed by the balance skills and the level of difficulty of the maneuvers. She'd like to use her knowledge as a physiotherapist to help skateboarders.

"Imilla" means "girl" or "young lady" in Quechua and Aymara, the most widely spoken Native languages in Bolivia.
“We want to motivate the female skateboarding scenario in Bolivia so this sport can grow and we can get more spaces to practice—so we can participate in sports tournaments around the world as other athletes do," says one member of the skating group. "Another thing we want to do is to show that no matter how you look, how old you are, or what’s your gender, you can be part of the skate community and feel the freedom of skateboarding. We believe that everyone deserves respect, and we must get rid of discrimination and mistreatment towards people who are different from you. Diversity makes beauty.”

For more about ImillaSkate and fighting discrimination against Indigenous people, check the January issue of National Geographic. Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 22, 2023. May be an image of 1 person, standing, tree and outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @alessandro.cinque | I left my native Italy to work in Peru, where I've lived for more than six years. During that time, I've been focused on covering the communities of the Andes. They've endured centuries of discrimination, pollution, and economic stagnation, despite the mineral wealth around them. Their tipping point came in December, when many rose up to join the biggest protests in decades in Lima.

Peru has been dubbed an economic miracle, but there's a stark urban-rural contrast: in its mountains you see abject poverty, inequality, and the racial divide that underpins both. The southern Andes hold most of the country’s vast copper reserves, but while mining companies earn profits and Peru’s tax coffers fill up, the benefits don't extend to the surrounding Indigenous communities.

Over 50 Peruvians have died—most from the southern Andes—in the protests that erupted in the chaos of a power struggle and the subsequent impeachment of then president Castillo, who many protestors identified with.

This selection of images shows a couple protest scenes, but mostly daily life in the Andes (in image 5, a woman mourns her stillborn calf, which died the day before).

To see more of my work, please follow @alessandro.cinque.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 22, 2023. May be a black-and-white image of 2 people, child and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @katieorlinsky | In 2015 Dave Dalton and his dog team cross Eagle Summit in the Alaska interior, the most challenging section of the Yukon Quest, a 1,000-mile (1,600 km) sled dog race. Alaska's sled dog racing season is currently in full swing; it's a tradition with over 3,000 years of history in the Arctic Circle. Indigenous communities there used sled dogs long before Europeans bred the animals for transportation and hauling as they colonized the region in the 19th century. It wasn’t until the 1960s, when highways were built and snowmobiles became widespread, that dogs were no longer needed for transport. Still, the practice of mushing, as traveling by sled dog is known, remained a cultural and recreational activity in communities across the Arctic, and the world of competitive racing began.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 21, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and nature.

ph_descripcion:
Read the full story at the link in bio.

Nearly all women suffer from hot flashes during menopause. Researchers have finally figured out what triggers them—paving the way for the first new class of treatments since 1941.

Illustration by My Box, Alamy Stock Photo
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 21, 2023. May be an image of text that says 'Is it possible to cure hot flashes? We may be getting closer.'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | Maasai herdsmen discuss lions as a storm brews behind them. During the period in which this image was shot, lion predation on cattle in the area around the village of Talek, on the edge of Kenya's Masai Mara Reserve, was high. The Maasai had been grazing their cattle inside the reserve in day and night shifts, bringing them into regular contact with the local lions. The result was a strange relationship: the lions developed strategies to hunt the cattle, mainly at night, and the Maasai learned to avoid them by texting each other the locations of the lions. It was exhilarating and terrifying to photograph—on foot—at night, and I was amazed by the bravery of the guys, who would run right up to the lions, throwing stones to scare them off. The lions would usually stand their ground, growling aggressively, and although they do occasionally attack, I never witnessed it.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 21, 2023. May be an image of 4 people, people standing and lightning.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | In 2013, when I first visited this spot in the Schwarzmooskogel ice cave, the rocks and boulders were almost completely buried by ice. Today much of it has melted, exposing the rocks. In the background, the impressive snow cone for which this hall is named is also shrinking. It’s a sad sight to see. In the article "When the Magic Melts," in the October issue, I document the contributions of scientists—and tour guides—as they work against the clock in this rapidly disappearing landscape. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @shonephoto for more.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 21, 2023. May be an image of nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | Alberto Sánchez, a scientist and curator of the herpetological collection at the National Museum of Natural Sciences in Madrid, holds a desert monitor (Varanus griseus) that had become trapped in a cistern in Western Sahara. Thousands of animals fall in these water wells throughout Morocco and other countries where water is scarce. What’s good for humans can be a deathtrap for some animals, which can enter these spaces seeking shelter, food, or water. They often die by drowning when the wells fill with water, or by starvation or dehydration when the wells run dry—often in a short time because of the high temperatures reached in these rooms. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to see more amazing creatures. #reptiles #conservation #westernsahara #animals
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 20, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @stephenwilkes | The magic of winter light shines through in this series on Block Island, Rhode Island. To see more from my travels near and far, follow me. #magic #winter #light #clouds #color #photography
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 20, 2023. May be an image of cloud and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @stephenwilkes | The magic of winter light shines through in this series on Block Island, Rhode Island. To see more from my travels near and far, follow me. #magic #winter #light #clouds #color #photography
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 20, 2023. May be an image of flower, nature and sky.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @beverlyjoubert | A bad "hair" day can afflict us all… The black heron may look comically disheveled here, but its hunting savvy is nothing to snigger at—and the watery landscapes of Botswana’s Okavango Delta are the perfect place to deploy one of the most ingenious and crafty fishing tactics in the avian world. The bird's "umbrella" method (also known as canopy feeding) involves spreading out those dark wings to create a shadowy trap for unsuspecting prey. Drawn in by the illusion of a shady hideaway, fish are soon dispatched by a few flicks of the heron's beak.

To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

#birds #blackheron #birdwatchers
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 20, 2023. May be an image of wading bird, body of water and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @jimmychin | June 2, 2017: A portrait of @alexhonnold the day before he free soloed—climbing without the assistance of ropes or gear—the rock known as El Capitan in California's Yosemite National Park. Often with only a quarter of a finger pad in contact with the rock, he made history the next day, June 3, achieving what many had thought impossible. For the full story, go to the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 20, 2023. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @jimmychin | June 2, 2017: A portrait of @alexhonnold the day before he free soloed—climbing without the assistance of ropes or gear—the rock known as El Capitan in California's Yosemite National Park. ph_descripcion: Photo by @brianskerry | Happy World Whale Day! A pod of orca swim off Dominica. Orca sightings are quite rare in the Caribbean, and these are believed to be the first images of orca near Dominica. There were eight animals in this group. For more on whale culture, go to the link in bio. #WorldWhaleDay #Orca #Whales
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 19, 2023. May be an image of outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @paoloverzone | Paleontologist Paul Sereno holds a fossil of a human jaw discovered during excavations at the Gobero site in Agadez, Niger. Taking the name given to the area by the Tuareg, nomads who have ruled that region for centuries, the site offers a glimpse of the Green Sahara, an era of time between 10,000 and 5,000 years ago when the land was lush with vegetation. People known as Kiffians were the first to settle in Gobero more than 9,700 years ago. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 19, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @acacia.johnson | A brown bear rests in the tundra near the boundary of Alaska's Izembek National Wildlife Refuge, close to the southern tip of the Alaska Peninsula. A proposed road connecting the nearby communities of King Cove and Cold Bay is the subject of a decades-long controversy: While residents of King Cove want improved access to medical care via the all-weather airport at Cold Bay, the road would cross through a globally important bird and wildlife habitat in the Izembek refuge. The land swap required to build the road would also upend a decades-old law that protects tens of millions of acres of Alaska's public lands, setting a precedent that could endanger all of the state's wildlife refuges.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 19, 2023. May be an image of animal, mountain and nature.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Pete McBride @pedromcbride | "Whiskey is for drinking; water is for fighting.” It seems this quote, attributed by some to Mark Twain, holds true, as the seven states that rely on the Colorado River couldn’t unanimously agree on a plan to cut 20-40% of water usage recently (six states did).

I’ve been covering this story for 15-plus years, following the river from source to the sea and walking (and paddling) its delta. Sadly, it's like watching a slow-motion train wreck.

We have already dried up the river's delta—formerly the largest desert estuary in North America—nearly drained its reservoirs, and dried up its tributaries. Somehow we continue to pretend water comes from our taps while ignoring the impacts that a two-decade-long drought, climate change, and overallocation are having on this Southwest lifeline.

I will continue to work on this story and the tragedy of the commons—as the saying goes—in my "backyard river" until I can’t. Collaboration and awareness are the only tools I’ve seen work to remedy this challenge. For more on the Colorado River, follow @pedromcbride.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 18, 2023. May be an image of nature and road.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @brentstirton | Happy World Pangolin Day! A patient caregiver at a secret site in Zimbabwe cares for a rescued pangolin, helping the traumatized animal find ants and termites to eat and keeping him safe from predators and traffickers. Pangolins are the world’s most trafficked nonhuman mammals, highly prized in Asia for their meat as a delicacy and their scales as part of traditional medicine. The Tikki Hywood Foundation undertakes public awareness campaigns about pangolins, trains law enforcement and judiciary personnel, conducts research, and rehabilitates animals that have been confiscated from the illegal trade. Based in Zimbabwe, it operates with partners across Africa. The trust also engages with other organizations and governments throughout Africa to highlight the plight of pangolins, raising awareness of their conservation status and helping people learn about caring for rescued pangolins. #WorldPangolinDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 18, 2023. May be an image of 1 person, pangolin and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | In western Florida, at a small interpretive center in Ellie Schiller Homosassa Springs Wildlife State Park, visitors can view a manatee skeleton and learn about the manatee's role in the ecosystem. The park has been a tourist attraction since the early 1900s, when trains stopped to let passengers off to walk the short trail to the spring. Homosassa Springs has four rehabilitating manatees: Two are permanent because they were rescued as juveniles and never acquired the life skills they needed to survive in the wild.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 18, 2023. May be an image of 3 people, people standing and indoor.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @craigcutlerstudio | Since at least the 17th century, origami has existed as an art, but today it’s getting a second life as it is now used for science and design as well. We photographed this entire story on a black background, which became the ultimate challenge because the objects ranged from the size of a pea to the size of a starshade that was 10 meters (30 ft) across.

The crane was folded from a single sheet of paper by origami artist and physicist Robert J. Lang. The complexity of this form was once thought to be nearly impossible. The rabbit was folded from a pattern generated by the Organizer, a computer program designed by Tomohiro Tachi for creating complex-faceted shapes. The program helped spur a recent explosion of origami models. Read the full story at the link in bio.

For more of my work, follow me at @craigcutlerstudio and @cutlerbremner.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 17, 2023. May be an image of bird and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @davillasana | In the wake of twin catastrophic earthquakes in Türkiye and Syria, more than 40,000 lives have been lost and millions displaced. The deadliest in Türkiye’s modern history, the quake has affected dozens of cities and villages. As rescue teams from around the world continue to search for survivors amid the rubble, the UN has launched a $1-billion-dollar appeal to support the more than five million people in need of aid. For single mothers like Gülbahar Bicer (third image), the help couldn’t come fast enough. Currently living in a tent on the side of the road in İskenderun with her three sons and a mother-in-law who has with cardiac issues, she eagerly awaits news of admission into a camp for internally displaced people. “My children’s psychology is broken,” she said. Follow @davillasana for more stories about the impact and rebuilding
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 17, 2023. May be an image of 9 people, monument and outdoors.
