ph_descripcion:
Photo by @moisessaman | Four-year-old Alloua Anooga lies on a traditional mud-brick wall at his family’s home in Tiebele, Burkina Faso. The village has some of the best preserved remaining examples of traditional painted Burkinabe architecture.

Crafted from mud and designed to allow for ventilation, the houses are then finished with coats of decorative paint that protect the dwellings from the rain. Despite the local king’s determination to preserve traditional ways of home construction, most locals have moved outside the royal court, or compound, in order to be able to build with concrete or in other nontraditional ways. There is a popular perception that concrete equates to modernity and that earth bricks are a symbol of poverty and backwardness. In addition, some local Christian and Muslim clerics see traditional architecture as an extension of animist beliefs, so they advise residents against living in mud-brick homes after they have converted to Christianity or Islam. NGOs and community elders are pushing back, hoping that cultural and ethnic identity will persuade some families to reembrace their cultural architecture tradition. Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 17, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | Reindeer battle heavy winds in Sweden's Sarek National Park. Unlike other deer species, reindeer females grow antlers and keep them throughout the winter. The antlers help them defend their food sources in a harsh environment. Follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images from the Nordic countries. #Sarek #Laponia #Lapland #reindeer #rangifertarandus
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 17, 2023. May be an image of deer and nature.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Aaron Huey @argonautphoto | These are hundred million-year-old microfossils called radiolarians. What I am photographing here are fossilized skeletons of these marine plankton. And I'm doing that with electrons instead of light because they're smaller than a speck of dust. For this project, I've had the incredible fortune to use the world's smallest scanning electron microscope (SEM) to photograph radiolarians in my own backyard for several months now. After 150 hours of scanning, I ended up with some unique images! Each individual image is made from 20 to 60 images shot in a grid stitched together.

These skeletons help scientists study global warming because their chemical signatures can tell us about ocean health back through millions of years. I'd seen images of radiolarians many times, but they were almost always perfect and singular scientific specimens. For this ongoing body of work, I'm focusing on making images that are more poetic than scientific, searching for radiolarians that were locked in an embrace or dance by the chance connection of some parts of their spines, which happened millions of years after their death. Most SEM devices are quite large, but this one is portable and a first of its kind. It's the size of a toaster and was made to travel—even ending up on the International Space Station at one point!
For more of my images and stories about radiolarians, follow @argonautphoto #InnovationDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 16, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Reuben Wu @reuben | The harvest moon appears to hover above one of the giant turbines at Block Island Wind Farm, the first commercial offshore wind farm in the United States, operating since December 2016.

By complete chance, the day of this shoot coincided with a full moon. Once I figured out what was possible, I was able to plan my exact location, altitude, helicopter flight time, and camera setup to make the perfect alignment. For more photos and stories, follow me @reuben.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 16, 2023. May be an image of nature and text.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @luisadorr | Brenda is a member of ImillaSkate, a women's skateboarding group in Cochabamba, Bolivia.

Brenda and her mother are Indigenous Aymara and considered to be pollera women because of the colorful traditional skirts—polleras—they wear. Brenda started skateboarding 6 years ago and found that it gave her direction and helped her overcome fear. "It makes me feel capable because I can break my own limits and I can dare to do things that I have never thought about," she says. "And like this I can get over my daily fear."

It's very hard to skateboard wearing a voluminous skirt, but Brenda has been improving her skills through perseverance and practice. For her, skateboarding with ImillaSkate represents her roots, the place she comes from, and who she is.

For more about ImillaSkate and fighting discrimination against Indigenous people, check the January issue of National Geographic. Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 16, 2023. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | Generally speaking, smaller animals have shorter life spans than larger ones, but bats break the rule. Eighteen of the 19 mammals that live proportionally longer than humans based on body size are bats. (The naked mole rat is the other.) This spectacularly colored yellow-winged bat, with soft gray fur and long, translucent ears, reminds me of how diverse these flying mammals are, with nearly 1,400 species living everywhere on the globe, except for extreme desert and polar regions. Read the January 2023 story about the science of longevity, and how to live longer and better, at the link in bio. To see more of my work on the interdependence of humans and nature, please follow @nicholesobecki. Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 15, 2023. May be an image of indoor.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @danwintersphoto | With its Artemis program, NASA is aiming to return astronauts to the moon by 2024. In this diptych, astronauts Zena Cardman (left) and Drew Feustel wear 100-pound space suit mock-ups. I photographed them following a four-hour moonwalk simulation in the Arizona desert, part of their training for future missions on the lunar surface.

Also in these images: The pressurized lunar rover, sitting above an extinct volcanic crater in the desert, is equipped with sleeping accommodations as well as sanitation and sustenance.

Feustal (right) and Cardman traverse the landscape with a supply cart while participating in training exercise in the crater, designed to simulate moonwalking conditions on the lunar south pole.

Japanese astronauts Norishige Kanai (left) and Akihiko Hoshide maneuver over the rocky volcanic terrain in the rover.

Follow me @danwintersphoto for continuing coverage of the NASA Artemis program. @nasa @nasaartemis @nasaastronauts @zenanaut @astro_feustel #artemis #moonwalk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 15, 2023. May be an image of nature.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @hannahreyesmorales | Birds fly over the city of Hatay, Turkey, at dusk. Hundreds of thousands of Syrians who fled the conflict in their country have taken refuge in this area near the Syrian border.

I made the image in late 2019 for a story on lullabies. I documented Syrian families who took lullabies with them as they left, passing them on to children as a way to preserve a sense of home and safety amid destruction.

It's hard to find the words when I see images of the aftermath of last week's earthquake here. For families escaping conflict, the disaster intensifies an already extremely difficult situation. Please consider donating to reputable organizations working on the ground.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 15, 2023. May be an image of bird and sky.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @kiliiiyuyan | Mikhail Bahe feeds her baby on a traditional Navajo cradleboard, or awéétsʼáál, in her family’s modern hogan on the Navajo Nation in Arizona. Traditional Diné parents like Mikhail use cradleboards to keep their babies safe until they are ready to crawl—a technology that's evolved over thousands of years of parental love. Follow me, @kiliiiyuyan, for more from the worlds of Indigenous communities, and stay tuned more images of love as National Geographic celebrates #ValentinesDay.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 14, 2023. May be an image of 2 people, child and indoor.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | A male sun glass frog (Hyalinobatrachium aureoguttatum) stands guard over a heart-shaped egg clutch in the Ecuadorian Chocó rainforest. This father will kick out any animal trying to prey on its offspring, and gather dew from leaves to keep the eggs hydrated until they hatch into tadpoles. As with many other glass frog species, dads help their young reach the next habitat: the water, where the tadpoles will spend some time before returning to the forest. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to discover more amazing frogs. This image of paternal care is part of a series celebrating love on #ValentinesDay.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 14, 2023. May be a closeup of nature.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @yagazieemezi | When I was asked to choose an image to tie to Valentine’s Day, I pondered which one could hold all the meanings we often place on the day. Then I remembered this 2018 portrait of Shari, Kobby, and their son in Accra, Ghana. It was a favorite photographic moment for me—I had the joy of being welcomed into it. They've since divorced but happily co-parent. I reached out to them for their permission to once again share the sweet family scene along with their feelings about it. Here's what they said:

"It was such a profoundly tender picture. We had friends and family reach out for weeks after it first went online, either complimenting us or telling us they would never have shared such an intimate shot. We wanted to blow it up, frame it, and hang it over our bed. It captured something of what we wanted our family to be.

Much has changed since then. Yet thankfully some things have not. It remains crucial to us both that he continues to know what love looks like; that he still feels as safe and as held as he was in the picture. And that starts with how we treat him and each other—with respect and kindness, patience and genuine care. We want him to know that love isn't just roses and Valentine's Day cards. Sometimes, it's messy, hard-won, and unconventional. But we too are what love looks like. And we're very proud of that."
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 14, 2023. May be an image of 2 people and body of water.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @brianskerry | A female humpback whale and her newborn calf (estimated to be two days old) swim in the waters off Rarotonga in the Cook Islands. Humpback whale mothers invest a great deal of energy into their calves. The gestation period is about a year long, and once the calf is born, mom spends another year teaching it all the skills it will need to survive. Stay tuned for more images of love celebrating #ValentinesDay.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 14, 2023. May be an image of outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @amivitale | Wildlife keeper Lekupania receives a nuzzle from an orphaned giraffe at @sararafoundation on Namunyak Wildlife Sanctuary in northern Kenya. A Samburu warrior, Lekupania used to look after his family’s livestock until he become an animal whisperer. He saved Fupi, the giraffe in this photograph, who had been injured after falling into a ditch. Since then, Fupi has been rehabilitated and returned to the wild by Lekupania, along with a number of other giraffes. Now all the rehabilitated giraffes come every morning to check on Lekupania. They do rounds of the stables and greet him, then make their way back to the wild. Follow @sararafoundation, @r.e.s.c.u.e, and @amivitale to learn more, including how to help ongoing conservation efforts. Stay tuned for more images of love celebrating #valentinesday. #giraffe #conservation #kenya #africa #babyanimals #kisses
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 14, 2023. May be an image of 1 person, animal, outdoors and text that says 'JAM JAM 3AMACA JAMALA'.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Robin Hammond @hammond_robin | “We met on our job. Eventually, we had to admit that we were attracted to one another. A couple of years later, we decided that we loved each other and wanted to be together,” says Evelyn Jenkins Whitaker (at right). She and her wife, Sonja Jackson, have been together for 18 years. Their families, they say, have “embraced us.”

For six years, in 14 countries, I recorded stories from LGBTQ folks for my project Where Love Is Illegal. Sadly, not all families are as accepting as Evelyn and Sonja’s. Many people told me it was their relatives whose discrimination was the most intense and most damaging. With each Valentine’s Day, it is my hope that we move closer toward recognizing that love is love—nothing else should matter. You can see Evelyn and Sonja’s story, and many others, at @whereloveisillegal. #ValentinesDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 14, 2023. May be an image of 2 people and indoor.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @erintrieb | Love comes in all shapes and sizes. For Stuart Breidenstein and Abby Dubief, it's a 26-foot-long yellow school bus named Maude.

The couple gave up their apartment lease in 2020, with plans to live for only a few months in the bus, purchased at an online auction for the Bend-La Pine School District in Oregon. (Breidenstein says he had his eye on the bus for years and waited for it to go on sale.) But when COVID-19 hit in March of that year, the bus became their full-time residence. The couple says living rent free while roaming North America’s West Coast has provided them with freedom and liberties they didn't have before.

"We don't have landlords or any of that so we really feel like we're on our own," he says. "We're in charge of our own destiny and happiness."

Breidenstein and Dubief, both artists, run Bright Place Gallery and plan to open a brick-and-mortar shop in Riley, Oregon, in the spring. Currently they're traveling in the eastern part of the Sierra Nevada range with their cat, Leonard.

Photographed here in June 2021, the couple enjoys reading and sketching inside the bus, and often sit by the fireside in the evening. Follow along for more #valentinesday vignettes.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 13, 2023. May be an image of bus and outdoors.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @jasperdoest | We know kissing as a greeting and as a way of expressing love, desire, and respect. But what about monkeys? Do they also kiss?

Yes. Some species, such as macaques and baboons, will often make communication gestures known as lip-smacking, which can lead to contact with the lips. It usually occurs between adult female monkeys and their young infants.

Aside from kissing, monkeys will hug and groom each other. Grooming is a way to show affection and respect. It helps to reduce tension by lowering the heart rate and releasing endorphins, the "feel-good" hormones. Follow @jasperdoest for more images of the wonders of nature. #monkeylove #kiss #valentinesday
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 13, 2023. May be an image of nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @celestesloman | Portrait of twin brothers and models Hector and Jan Carlos Diaz, 24, in New York City. Stay tuned for more images celebrating the love of family members, partners, animals, and more for #ValentinesDay.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 13, 2023. May be an image of 1 person, flower and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Prasenjeet Yadav @prasen.yadav | The snow leopard evolved to live in the high-elevation desert of India's Himalayan range, and every part of its body shows adaptations to this environment. Take the nose, for example. Large nostrils and a broad nasal cavity make it easier for the snow leopard to inhale large amounts of oxygen-poor mountain air. The nasal cavity houses particularly large and thick mazes of bone and tissue called turbinates. When a snow leopard inhales freezing air into the turbinates, the air becomes heated as it mixes with warm air exiting the lungs. Now that's an incredible life hack that evolution has provided to these big cats. Follow me at @prasen.yadav for more photos from India.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 13, 2023. May be an image of big cat.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | This photograph was made during the February 2013 nor'easter, also known as winter storm Nemo, as I wandered through Central Park. New York City was a home base from 2005 to 2017. And while all cities are unique and special in their own way, living in here in my 20s and 30s was magical. The experience recalls what Hemingway wrote about Paris: “If you are lucky enough to have lived in Paris as a young man, then wherever you go for the rest of your life, it stays with you, for Paris is a moveable feast.”
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 13, 2023. May be an image of 4 people, child, tree, nature, snow and street.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | Rats raid a trash can on a street corner in Manhattan's Tribeca district. New York City's rats are famous, not just because of "Pizza Rat" (the star of a video that aired in 2017 showing the rodent dragging a slice of pizza down the stairs of a subway station) but because there are so many of them. Despite popular myth, the rats are not very big—not the size of dogs or cats or other exaggerations people have as they stumble across the creatures on the sidewalk and leap out of their skin. If you want to find and photograph a rat in NYC, it's pretty easy: Just head to a restaurant or bodega (a food source) near a nice catch basin or building site (a secure home), and chances are you'll see rats scuttling between the two as they stuff their little faces with all the good stuff we chucked out.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 12, 2023. May be an image of rat, outdoors and text that says 'MOR'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @edkashi | A couple dances at a fisherman's wedding in the village of Crișan, Romania, where a quarter of the population is ethnic Ukrainian, on February 17, 2001. Stay tuned for more joyful moments in celebration of #valentinesday.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 12, 2023. May be an image of 4 people and people standing.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @alessandro.cinque | An alpaca fetus is analyzed under a microscope at the Quimsachata Research and Production Center in the Puno region of southeastern Peru. The center, using a process that includes insemination and embryo transfers, aims to create genetically “improved” alpacas that offer higher fiber quality and are more resilient to disease and the effects of climate change. Indigenous communities often raise money to buy one of these specimens to add to their livestock. Tens of thousands of families depend on alpacas for their livelihoods, but climate change poses a growing risk to the animals and the communities they sustain. The Andes are experiencing shorter but more intense rainy seasons and longer periods of drought. Frosts and hailstorms have become more common. Changing weather patterns are shrinking natural pastures and reducing grass quality, forcing alpaca herds to compete for food. Read the full story at the link in bio, and to see more of my work, please follow @alessandro.cinque.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 12, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @beverlyjoubert | For lion cubs in the wilds of Botswana, the odds of survival can be precariously low—and it's often their mother’s care and fierce dedication that will be the deciding factor in beating those odds. She must shield her young from hunger and the elements, protect them from the menace of rival carnivores, and impart those critical early skills they’ll need to survive in the rough-and-tumble world of a top predator. Yet even amid the grueling work of motherhood, there is always time for a tender moment of grooming and affectionate nuzzling. It’s heartwarming to witness the ties that bind in the animal kingdom for #valentinesday. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.
#lioncub #bigcatsofinstagram #wildlife
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 12, 2023. May be an image of big cat and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @timlaman | A female Pennant's red colobus in early morning light. This critically endangered species is endemic to Bioko island, in Equatorial Guinea. I photographed the monkey and many others on a RAVE, a Rapid Assessment Visual Expedition, for National Geographic. Follow me @timlaman for more wildlife and bird photographs. #wildlifephotography #conservation #wildlife #BiokoIsland
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 11, 2023. May be an image of nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Agho kisses his granddaughter, Ehizogie, outside his home in Abomey, Benin. Stay tuned for more intimate family moments in honor of #valentinesday.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 11, 2023. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @stephenwilkes | Reflecting Pool, Lincoln Memorial, Washington, DC. On a dark and gray winter’s day, I spotted the subtle yet perfect illumination of the thousands of coins tossed in the pool. At first glance, they looked like stars in the night sky. Make a wish! To see more from my travels near and far, follow me @stephenwilkes. #wish #pool washingtondc #reflection #coins #nightsky
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 11, 2023. May be an image of tree, nature and sky.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @paoloverzone | The mummy of Tiye, with a head of hair perfectly preserved, is one of the most important artifacts in the collection of the National Museum of Egyptian Civilization in Cairo. DNA testing in 2010 identified the Elder Lady, as she had been called since her discovery in 1898, as Queen Tiye, grandmother of Tutankhamun, mother of Akhenaten, and wife of Amenhotep III. She was one of the most powerful queens in Egyptian history. Tiye is on display at the museum’s magnificent Royal Mummies’ Hall. The museum, which opened in 2017, features 50,000 artifacts that tell the story of Egyptian civilization from prehistoric times to the present day. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 11, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @beckythale | A western lowland gorilla, called Calaya by zookeepers, carries her newborn, Moke, at the National Zoo in Washington, DC. They were photographed for a story on animal milk banks. To read the full story, go to the link in bio. This image of parental care is part of a series celebrating love on #ValentinesDay.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @renaeffendiphoto | I'm based in Turkey, and I had taken these images in the cities of Gaziantep and Antakya in 2019 and 2022. Near the border with Syria, the region is a melting pot where cultures and cuisines blended and fused in a remarkable way. I remember the warmth from the communal ovens in the bazaars of Antakya, where neighbors brought their dough to turn it into delicious bread, and the intoxicating whiffs of sumac, za'atar, and other spices that followed me everywhere. I met so many kind people who opened up their doors and welcomed me into their homes and fed me.

Disaster hit in the early hours on Monday, February 6, when a 7.8 magnitude quake struck near Gaziantep followed by an equally strong tremor. As the tragedy continues to unfold, with so many people still stranded under the rubble, I also can't help thinking about the monumental loss for humanity, global culture, and heritage. Please consider supporting reputable organizations working on the ground to help the victims of this devastated region across Turkey and Syria. #earthquake #gaziantep #antakya #turkey #crisis #disaster #syria
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 10, 2023. May be an image of fire, food and outdoors.

Bats have long been sold in local markets in their range countries for meat, souvenirs, or traditional medicine. Yet the online trade amplifies the threat to bats and creates a different and greater demand.

Photograph by Merlin Tuttle, Science Source
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 10, 2023. May be an image of text that says 'Dead bats are being turned into trinkets and sold online. Scientists are disturbed.'.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @michaelchristopherbrown | In the Pacific Northwest, potent Psilocybe (psychedelic) mushrooms are thriving in urban landscaped environments. Of the dozen or so common, woodchip-loving mushrooms that grow there, three are of particular interest to magic mushroom hunters—the potent Psilocybe cyanescens, Psilocybe allenii, and Psilocybe ovoideocystidiata (above). For the full story in the article “A psychedelic surprise may be thriving in your local garden,” go to the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 10, 2023. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and nature.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | I’ve spoken before about my work documenting the rewilding of Saudi Arabia and the Arabian leopard as a powerful symbol of restoration and regeneration. I’ve spent days and days sitting calmly, waiting and watching these magnificent creatures. Although it can be frustrating (I’m not a patient person), I’m extremely happy to find that my work is becoming more difficult, more complex, with the arrival of each new cub. Here, we see the latest one.

Born at the Arabian leopard breeding center in Taif, Saudi Arabia, these apex predators will one day be released back into this ecosystem. The center is operated by the Royal Commission for AlUla (RCU). This winter, RCU is releasing more than 1,500 Arabian gazelles, sand gazelles, Arabian oryx, and Nubian ibex into their ancestral habitat. The last piece of the puzzle will be the return of the Arabian leopard. Before that happens, the land will need to be re-greened to support the prey, as the pyramid of a functioning ecosystem rises from the desert sand. One day, this leopard will sit in these mountains and watch from a great distance as people walk by, unaware of its presence. Until then, the longer it takes for me to see it here, the better its chances of survival are in the wild.

Today, February 10, marks the second Arabian Leopard Day, which sheds light on the plight of this majestic creature and the conservation work under way to ensure its survival. To see more on this story, follow me @chancellordavid.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 10, 2023. May be an image of big cat.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Zoo Tampa’s Manatee Critical Care Center has three 16,000-gallon medical treatment pools, two underwater treatment pools, and a public observation area. This view gives visitors a real-time understanding of the steps taken to care for rehabilitating manatees. Here animal care supervisor Jaime Vaccaro uses an underwater vacuum to remove algae, leftover lettuce, and feces from the tank.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 09, 2023. May be an image of indoor.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @isadorakosofsky | Jeanie Thompson, 81, and Will Seward, 84, kiss on the sidewalk in Los Angeles. Jeanie and Will met at a retirement community in East Hollywood. But this photograph tells only one part of their story. In 2011 Will was evicted from a retirement community where he shared an apartment with Adina, a longtime companion. He moved into another assisted-living community nearby, where he met Jeanie. They connected immediately. Torn between Adina and Jeanie, Will tried to maintain a relationship with both. Eventually, after a period of discomfort, conflict, and uncertainty, Jeanie and Adina accepted the unconventional dynamic. “There are many different kinds of love,” said Adina. Jeanie, Will, and Adina formed a trio, often spending days roaming around the east side of Los Angeles. Their relationship challenged sociocultural norms and stereotypes about how older adults should live their lives. More than anything, their time together revealed ageless questions about freedom, romantic love, the nature of intimacy, and what constitutes a relationship. To see more stories on older adults and relationships, follow me at @isadorakosofsky.

In honor of Valentine's Day, we are posting images about love in its many forms. #ValentinesDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 09, 2023. May be an image of 3 people, people standing, road and street.

ph_descripcion:
We are honoring the pioneering deep-sea photographer and longtime National Geographic Explorer Emory Kristof, who passed away on February 6 at the age of 80. Known particularly for his iconic photos of the discovery of the Titanic, Kristof took readers to places they could never reach.

“Emory made a difference in how we see the sea,” says David Doubilet, a fellow photographer who collaborated on stories with Kristof for decades. “I covered the first 200 feet [60m] of depth, and he took the rest. And the rest was thousands of feet beneath our hull.”

Kristof pushed the technical boundaries of photography and was a pioneer of using submersibles to show parts of the world previously unknown, including deep-sea vents. “Emory tried to convince everyone he worked with that his current project was not only worthwhile but groundbreaking. And he was usually correct,” says former director of photography Kent Kobersteen. “His dedication to photography was unparalleled. He truly lived and breathed his projects.”

Kristof regularly contributed to the magazine from 1963 to 1994.

“He stood tall as a pioneer of the deep and now others stand on his shoulders to reach farther, or in this case, deeper—as it should be,” says @daviddoubilet.

Photos: The bow of the R.M.S. Titanic, as seen during its discovery in 1985; the Temple of Luxor complex in Egypt; a remotely piloted submersible is lifted from Lake Ontario, Canada; passengers inspect the Cayman wall from inside a submersible; the Eldfell volcano erupts in Vestmannaeyjar, Iceland, in 1973; women move scaffolding in Zanzibar, Tanzania; in Iceland, students take a swim lesson in a pool heated by geothermal wells; astronauts work on the Skylab in Alabama in 1973; a man and his donkey at sunset in Kenya; Kristof, aboard the Knorr vessel, poses with Argo, the submersible used in the discovery of the Titanic during the 1985 expedition.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 09, 2023. May be an image of 2 people, monument and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Daniella Zalcman @dzalcman | Gulls land on a small iceberg in the Arctic Ocean toward the end of summer, when the sea ice has reached its annual minimum. According to NASA, September Arctic sea ice is now shrinking at a rate of 12.6 percent a decade, which can lead to more intense summer heat waves, sea-level rise, and significant habitat destruction for wildlife populations.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 09, 2023. May be an image of arctic, nature and sky.

ph_descripcion: Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder | To slow Don Lueck’s dementia, his doctors suggested that he learn a new skill. He took up art in 2019 and has made more than 17,000 paintings. The hobby helped the gregarious 77-year-old endure pandemic-imposed isolation in his Madison, Wisconsin home. “Painting every day during this time saved our lives because his brain was actively engaged in a creative process he loves,” says his wife, Jenny Villwock. “He often includes faces or creatures in his painting—someone with whom he could socialize.” This portrait of Lueck, surrounded by some of his paintings, is part of the January 2023 cover story, “Living Longer—and Better: How Science Could Change the Way We Age.”
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 09, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and indoor.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | A vivid Mwanza flat-headed rock agama recharges under the sun, in Kenya's Masai Mara. Agama lizards are widely distributed throughout Africa, with a total of at least 37 species. To see more photos from this part of the world, please visit me @ladzinski.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 08, 2023. May be an image of nature.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @babaktafreshi | Swipe to see a larger view of aurora rays. Each August I organize a stargazing and photography retreat in Maine. Participants are often surprised to learn that the northern lights frequently can be spotted at this midlatitude. To the naked eye, they're mostly colorless spikes on the horizon, but strikingly colorful with a camera. As we approach the next peak, in 2024-25, in the 11-year cycle of solar activity, major eruptions from the sun will create stronger aurora displays on Earth.

Aurora is formed around the geomagnetic poles, which are currently about 10 degrees off the geographic poles and slowly drifting. The north geomagnetic pole is at 80°N, 73°W in Nunavut, Canada; sitting right above the eastern side of the U.S., it results in a 10-degree gain in magnetic latitude for North American observers. On Earth's opposite side, in Asia, it's extremely rare to see aurora from the same latitude, which is 20 degrees lower magnetically. In the Southern Hemisphere, Tasmania and New Zealand are favorable viewing spots near the south geomagnetic pole. The tip of South America (Patagonia) is in the least favorable position for seeing the lights. #astrophotography #aurora #northernlights #maine
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 08, 2023. May be an image of 1 person, nature and sky.

Aurora is formed around the geomagnetic poles, which are currently about 10 degrees off the geographic poles and slowly drifting. The north geomagnetic pole is at 80°N, 73°W in Nunavut, Canada; sitting right above the eastern side of the U.S., it results in a 10-degree gain in magnetic latitude for North American observers. On Earth's opposite side, in Asia, it's extremely rare to see aurora from the same latitude, which is 20 degrees lower magnetically. In the Southern Hemisphere, Tasmania and New Zealand are favorable viewing spots near the south geomagnetic pole. The tip of South America (Patagonia) is in the least favorable position for seeing the lights. #astrophotography #aurora #northernlights #maine
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 08, 2023. May be an image of 1 person, nature and sky.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @jenniferhayesig | A mother harp seal coaxes her pup into the water for a swimming lesson with a calming nose-to-nose kiss of recognition: I am your mother; you are my pup. She then guided the pup through icy water for several minutes until she detected several aggressive males circling below. Each February, harp seals are born on the sea ice in the Gulf of St. Lawrence in eastern Canada, and their mothers will nurse them for 12 to 15 days before she leaves to mate and migrate north to the Arctic. To survive, the pup relies on fat reserves and a few weeks of stable ice until it learns to swim and forage for food. This image is part of a series celebrating love on #ValentinesDay.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 08, 2023. May be an image of outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | While on assignment to photograph melting ice caves in the Alps, I observed that the formations inside Eiskogelhöhle in Austria (pictured) have not changed much since my first visit there, in 2013—the volume of ice is still the same. One possible theory could be that due to its high elevation, this cave carries cooler winds throughout the year and never really gets warm enough to melt the ice. It's over 500 meters (1,650 ft) higher than Schwarzmooskogel, which is melting fast. In "When the Magic Melts," my article in the October issue, author Denise Hruby and I document the contributions of scientists—and tour guides—as they work against the clock in this rapidly disappearing landscape. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @shonephoto for more.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 08, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and nature.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @hannahreyesmorales | This portrait of Marta and Apolinar is one of my favorites—and it reminds me of the healing power of love. They're seated on their bed, which is covered by mosquito netting. For Marta, an assault survivor, Apolinar's support was part of her healing process at a time when there was no support structure for victims. She was assaulted in a mass rape during World War II.

For situations like this, the question I ask myself is, how I can portray the complexity that comes with survival and healing without playing down the severity of the trauma we carry. Follow me @hannahreyesmorales for more stories from the Philippines and beyond. #ValentinesDay
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 07, 2023. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'sẽ'.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @williamodaniels | As a reporter, I often work abroad, but over the last year I turned my eye to my own country—France—to document climate change. According to the national weather agency, 2022 was both the hottest and driest year on record and marked by multiple disasters. Forest fires reached a record, with more than 62,000 hectares (153,000 acres) burned. Drought brought historically low harvests for farmers. The summer accelerated the decline of ice mass in the mountains, which show an unprecedented loss—experts estimate that glaciers will disappear in the Pyrenees Mountains within 30 years. This exceptional year may become the norm by 2050 if greenhouse gas emissions are not significantly reduced.

Above: A campsite near Dune du Pilat—Europe’s tallest sand dune, perched amid a forest on the Atlantic coast—was destroyed by fire.

Other images: A restaurant near Cazaux Lake in Gironde after one of the year's biggest fires; a drought-stricken sunflower field; and a dry lake near the Loire River.

A ski slope is protected from heat under a white blanket on La Grande Motte glacier in Tignes. In the past, Tignes had been open for summer skiing from mid-June to early September. It's gradually been reduced, and last year the summer season lasted only a week.

A dock for boats near Savines Lake; water levels of Serre-Ponçon, the biggest artificial lake in France, dropped by 13 meters (42 ft), and boats can no longer moor there.

In Gironde, a dry cornfield, campsite, and forest fell victim to drought and fire. Traditionally the southern region along the Mediterranean is prone to forest fires, but in 2022 they centered on the Gironde area, on the Atlantic side.

Last image: Burned trees near Salses-le-Château, in southern France.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 07, 2023. May be an image of beach.

The nation's six million feral pigs are destroying crops and preying on endangered species. But the most serious threat they pose is to human health.

Photograph by Rolf Nussbaumer, Nature Picture Library
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 07, 2023. May be an image of animal, outdoors and text that says '6 million hogs are running wild in the U.S. They're more dangerous than you think.'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | When I first visited Linfen, in 2010, just minutes after walking out of the central train station I saw through the hazy air this overgrown government building. China’s environmental protection agency said the coal belt city had the worst air in the country. At the time, the World Bank reported that 16 of the 20 most polluted cities were in China. Since then, Linfen’s government has made some efforts to clean up the city, ordering pollution controls such as closing substandard mines, limiting the traffic of coal trucks, and the promoting gas over coal as a heating source. There is controversy around the amount of progress in combatting the pollution, including criticism from the Chinese state itself.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 07, 2023. May be an image of outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @lisettepoole | Local Miguel Ángel Ziga Aragón, who goes by the name La Chavelona, poses for a portrait in Zipolite, in Mexico's Oaxaca state. The beach town is known as a laid-back and welcoming place for members of the LGBTQ community. Though a boom in tourism overall is transforming the area, causing accommodation prices to spike, to longtime visitors like Roberto Jerr from Mexico City (second), it remains a special place. Gender fluidity, body positivity, and freedom of expression motivate people to move here permanently, including Daniel Zamora (third), a tarot card reader, and Spaniard Blanca Sanchez (last). For more on this story and others from Latin America follow me @lisettepoole.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 06, 2023. May be a closeup of 1 person and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | In southwest England, a kingfisher attempts to feed her chicks at their riverbank nest. Kingfishers, despite being exquisitely handsome, are born blind, bald, and ugly—recalling the ugly duckling story. Mum and dad feed the chicks all day long for nearly a month, catching small fish along the river and bringing them back to the nest—a tunnel dug into the bank, with a small chamber at the end. Inside, it's almost completely dark, so the parents work by touch to find an open beak, stuffing in a fish headfirst. Successful broods will fledge between six and eight chicks.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 06, 2023. May be an image of bird.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Pete McBride @pedromcbride | A study in layers: The Grand Canyon's Bright Angel Trail descends 4,380 feet (1,335 m) from the 270 million-year-old Kaibab Formation to the 1.7-billion-year-old Zoroaster Granite on the river. Formed on the ocean floor, the Kaibab Limestone is the canyon's uppermost layer, sitting around 9,000 feet (2,700 m) in elevation due to the plate tectonics that uplifted the Colorado Plateau. For more from the Grand Canyon, follow @pedromcbride. #arizona #grandcanyon #travel #landscapes #geology
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 06, 2023. May be an image of nature.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @ralphpace | A juvenile southern sea otter (Enhydra lutris nereis) dives below a large wave on its way to find mussels to eat in Monterey Bay, California.

Although sea otters are generalists when it comes to feeding, they often prefer specific foods. As conditions change and the sea gets rougher, otters will still forage in very shallow waters when the seas are high.

As excellent swimmers capable of holding their breath for nearly 8 minutes, otters can stay below the heavy waves until smaller sets of waves come in or until they can swim to deeper waters.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 05, 2023. May be an image of nature and body of water.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @beckythale | When journalist Nikole Hannah-Jones showed up for a portrait wearing a fuchsia shirt, it was a gift. Sometimes I can influence the details of a shoot, but this project came together quickly. With just a few hours' notice, I hopped on the train from Washington, D.C., to New York City for the session. It's not often that I have the opportunity to photograph someone whose work I follow. Hannah-Jones's "The 1619 Project" has challenged me to think about the narratives that have shaped my identity and has stayed with me. And though she doesn't need a fuchsia shirt to make her extraordinary, I was grateful for it nonetheless. For the full story on her project, see the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 05, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio | La Gorce Arch, Glen Canyon, Utah. With a two-decade-long drought gripping the western United States, water levels in Lake Powell have plummeted, particularly during the last two years. A silver lining to the water crisis: over 100,000 acres (40,000 ha) of Glen Canyon are now out from under the artificial lake, revealing natural wonders such as La Gorce. As the waters retreat, a flood of flora and fauna is appearing at a pace greater than scientists anticipated, which brings hope for the restoration of one of America’s lost natural wonders—Glen Canyon. Follow me @elliotstudio as I continue to explore stories surrounding the Colorado River Basin.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 05, 2023. May be an image of nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | Red foxes, like this one @greenwoodwildlife, are mostly solitary, but that doesn’t mean they don’t have a lot to say. There have been more than 25 different kinds of vocalizations observed in red foxes, which are used to communicate to individuals both nearby and far away. Researchers have also found that foxes have their own distinct voices, so individuals can be distinguished from one another. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #fox #animal #wildlife #photography #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 05, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @moisessaman | At a quarry in Pissy, on the western edge of Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, men, women, and children—some younger than 10—extract granite that will be broken down to make concrete and gravel for house construction, exemplifying a move away from traditional building materials. The extraction process involves burning tires in order to create the heat necessary to crack massive slabs of granite, which are then broken down into ever smaller pieces and carried in large loads on the workers' heads up the quarry’s steep slopes. Quarry workers estimate that they burn at least 200 tires a day. The noxious fumes from the tires along with the extreme heat create hazardous working conditions for those who labor there for up to 14 hours a day. Although there are several mechanized quarries around Ouagadougou that have undercut prices, the quarry at Pissy persists because of the insatiable demand for new concrete housing.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 04, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | To understand aging, researchers look for clues in animals, such as those studied by the 51-year-old Amboseli Baboon Research Project in Kenya. As part of that work, Benard Oyath and Jackson Warutere prepare to take blood and other samples from Olduvai, who was tranquilized and then released back to the wild. The project’s scientists have found that baboons with strong social connections in adulthood can recover from harmful health effects of a stressful childhood. I am glad to see Olduvai included in the January 2023 magazine story about the science of longevity and how to live longer and better. To see more of my work on humanity’s connection to the natural world, please follow @nicholesobecki.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 04, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | A tent-making bat (Uroderma bilobatum) drinks water from a pond in the Ecuadorian Amazon. In this single frame, I used a flash on stroboscopic mode, lighting the bat three times in this sequence. Bats are invaluable for their ecological services: they disperse seeds, pollinate flowers, and feed on millions of insects, potentially limiting the spread of some viral diseases. Follow me @javier_aznar_photography to discover more about wildlife in the jungle. #bat #water #ecuador
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 04, 2023. May be an image of nature.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @paoloverzone | Egyptian archaeologist Zahi Hawass examines the mummy KV21B in a storage room at the Egyptian Museum in Cairo before performing DNA sampling and a CT scan to determine its family tree. This mummy was discovered with another, KV21A, in a tomb discovered in 1817 in the Valley of the Kings. Both mummies may be queens from the 18th dynasty. Hawass and other Egyptian archaeologists consider KV21B a candidate for the body of Nefertiti. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 04, 2023. May be an image of 1 person and indoor.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @brianskerry | A newborn beluga whale "smiles" for the camera. It's part of a beluga population that winters near Greenland and migrates through the Northwest Passage of Canada in summer. They often spend weeks in Cunningham Inlet, an estuary ecosystem in the high Arctic. Seawater temperatures hover around minus two degrees Celsius (29 F), but freshwater from a river flowing into the ocean is about four degrees warmer, making this a perfect place to give birth and nurse calves. Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 03, 2023. May be an image of body of water.

Read the full story at the link in bio.

The ability to read the skies was imperative to the survival of enslaved and free Africans, helping them track time, weather, and seasons. Now, Black astronomers are inspiring a new generation to enter the field.

Photograph by Babak Tafreshi @babaktafreshi, Nat Geo Image Collection
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 03, 2023. May be an image of sky and text that says 'Reading the night sky helped enslaved Africans survive. Today, Black Americans are reclaiming those ties.'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Blue Spring State Park in central Florida is a winter haven for about 800 manatees. Save the Manatee Club's Cora Berchem and Wayne Hartley do a daily count and general health checks during the winter. They can distinguish the manatees by their body scars from injuries such as being struck by boats. Having done this work for more than 30 years, Hartley has memorized hundreds of scar patterns.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 03, 2023. May be an image of ‎2 people, body of water and ‎text that says '‎RESEARCH ساب‎'‎‎.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @jimmychin | @alexhonnold and @felipe.camargo rappel from the Getu Arch, China, 2016. This was probably one of the harder rigging and shooting jobs in recent memory. We basically had to figure out how to move along the underside of the roof in an 800-foot-tall cave (240 m). Biggest challenge? Facing the wrong way from the action while spinning on the free-hanging rope in space.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 02, 2023. May be an image of nature.

Three recent criminal acts at the Dallas Zoo have alarmed officials, including the theft of two emperor tamarins that were later recovered. And it’s not the only zoo under threat.

Photograph taken in Manu National Park, Peru by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames, Nat Geo Image Collection
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 02, 2023. May be an image of text that says 'Two monkeys stolen. An endangered vulture killed. The Dallas Zoo is being sabotaged.'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | On a cold December day in Sweden's Sarek National Park, I came across this male ptarmigan. As I approached slowly, the bird did not flee—and I spent the whole day near this spot. For most of the day, the bird stayed under the cover of its snow cave, leaving the burrow only at the end of the day to feed. Please follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images from the Nordic countries. #Sarek #Laponia #Lapland #Sweden #ptarmigan #lagopusmuta
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 02, 2023. May be an image of nature and snow.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @norikohayashi_photo | Japan is introducing a variety of approaches and technologies to adapt to a rapidly aging population. The different strategies are developed and implemented by communities, neighborhoods, hamlets, and others, according to their specific needs, and enable Japanese to lead their lives in harmony with their values.

(1) Toyama, a city on Japan’s largest island, has striven to become a more hospitable place to grow old. One key initiative is the Kadokawa Preventive Care Center, which has exercise pools fed by hot springs. Every day about 250 older adults work out at the facility.

(2) In Japan, population decline and aging in rural areas are progressing rapidly. It is estimated that about 500 hamlets will disappear in the next 10 years, and this erosion will accelerate in the future. Toshie Ueno, 91, the last resident of a hamlet on Shikoku Island, feeds her cats just outside of her home.

(3) Hiromu Inada, 89, became the oldest triathlete ever to complete an Ironman World Championship in 2018. He started swimming at 60 after he retired and participated in his first triathlon when he was 70. He trains daily.

(4) Osamu Yamanaka, a 67-year-old physician, visits Kiichi Takahashi, 74, in his room in Kotobukicho, an area of Yokohama that is home to day laborers. Today there are about 120 small cheap lodging apartment buildings designated for older welfare recipients. Yamanaka runs a clinic in Kotobuchiko and helps his patients during their last stages of life.

(5) Genyu Daito, 64, the chief priest of Banshoji, a Buddhist temple in Nagoya, prays in a LED-lit ossuary that highlights niches when they are selected by an electronic ID card. Innovative burial options are becoming popular as the tradition of family tombs declines.

Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 02, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @norikohayashi_photo | Japan is introducing a variety of approaches and technologies to adapt to a rapidly aging population. The different strategies are developed and implemented by communities, neighborhoods, hamlets, and others, according to their specific needs, and enable Japanese to lead their lives in harmony with their values.

(1) Toyama, a city on Japan’s largest island, has striven to become a more hospitable place to grow old. One key initiative is the Kadokawa Preventive Care Center, which has exercise pools fed by hot springs. Every day about 250 older adults work out at the facility.

(2) In Japan, population decline and aging in rural areas are progressing rapidly. It is estimated that about 500 hamlets will disappear in the next 10 years, and this erosion will accelerate in the future. Toshie Ueno, 91, the last resident of a hamlet on Shikoku Island, feeds her cats just outside of her home.

(3) Hiromu Inada, 89, became the oldest triathlete ever to complete an Ironman World Championship in 2018. He started swimming at 60 after he retired and participated in his first triathlon when he was 70. He trains daily.

(4) Osamu Yamanaka, a 67-year-old physician, visits Kiichi Takahashi, 74, in his room in Kotobukicho, an area of Yokohama that is home to day laborers. Today there are about 120 small cheap lodging apartment buildings designated for older welfare recipients. Yamanaka runs a clinic in Kotobuchiko and helps his patients during their last stages of life.

(5) Genyu Daito, 64, the chief priest of Banshoji, a Buddhist temple in Nagoya, prays in a LED-lit ossuary that highlights niches when they are selected by an electronic ID card. Innovative burial options are becoming popular as the tradition of family tombs declines.

Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 02, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Pete McBride @pedromcbride | There are 18 species of penguins on Earth, each with its own distinguishing characteristics. King penguins (first photo) are the second largest, and easy to spot with their prominent yellow-orange feathers. Gentoo penguins (second) have bright beaks and a white patch on their heads. They swim up to 22 miles (35 km) per hour, making them the fastest diving bird. I've been lucky to see these and many more penguin types in Antarctica and on the islands north of the continent, where a warming climate puts pressures on all penguin species. For more wildlife, follow @pedromcbride.#antarctica #southgeorgia #penguins #wildlife #nature
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 01, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @laurakmorton | Over the last few years, moviegoers across the United States have been revitalizing a classic American pastime: the drive-in theater. Down from a high of about 4,000 in the late 1950s, an estimated 330 drive-ins remain in operation in the country—and the pandemic brought interest from new customers. On a road trip in 2020, I visited the Spud Drive-In Theatre, in Idaho’s Teton Valley region, which is named for the the state's chief crop and was built in 1953. For more photographs of people and places, follow along @laurakmorton.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 01, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Reuben Wu @reuben | On the Norwegian island of Spitsbergen, huge radomes making up the Svalbard Satellite Station seem to hover in the mist. From a series of images documenting the unearthly beauty of the ground station, which supports orbiting satellites. For more photos and stories, follow me @reuben.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on February 01, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @luisadorr | This is Dani, a member of the ImillaSkate women's skateboarding collective in Cochabamba, Bolivia. As a child, she was introduced to the skating world by her brother. In 2019, after she graduated from university, she bought her first skateboard and dedicated herself to practicing.

The word imilla means “young girl” in Aymara and Quechua, and the group performs in the traditional attire—pollera skirts and hats (and hair in braids)—of the country's Indigenous highland women. Dani says that her great-grandmother wore polleras, and dressing in the same style is a point of pride. For the full story, check out the January issue or go to the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 31, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | In Italy's Buso della Neve del Zingarella, time is recorded in layers upon layers of ancient ice—stored in this giant plug wedged between the rock walls of the cave. For Italian geologist and explorer Francesco Sauro, this is a special cave. Sauro recognizes the importance of sampling and studying this ice now, before it melts away and crashes to the floor, disappearing forever. In "When the Magic Melts," in the October issue, author Denise Hruby and I document the contributions of scientists—and tour guides—as they work against the clock in this rapidly disappearing landscape. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @shonephoto for more.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 31, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | For their first couple years of life, juvenile Peruvian spider monkeys like this one @rarec.center depend heavily on their mothers for everything from protection and transportation to vital nutrients obtained through mom’s milk. Once weaned, these primates will become important gardeners of their forested homes, consuming more than 130 species of fruit and dispersing the seeds. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #monkey #primate #animal #wildlife #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 31, 2023.

Seasonal affective disorder can occur in both winter and summer. Here's why it happens, and how you might treat it.

Photo Illustration by Jennifer Lee Blanton, Getty Images

ph_descripcion: Photo by @timlaman | I climbed a strangler fig tree in Borneo to capture this shot of a red leaf monkey (Presbytis rubicunda) mom and baby feeding on figs high in the rainforest canopy. The monkeys are known by many names, including maroon langur and maroon leaf monkey. I’m on my way home after working for six weeks in Indonesia on assignment for National Geographic. To see more rainforest wildlife visit me @timlaman. #borneo #indonesia #gunungpalungnationalpark #wildlifephotography #conservation #onassignment
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 30, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @erintrieb | Northern Indiana is home to major RV manufacturers, including Jayco, Winnebago, and Coachmen. About 80 percent of the RVs made in America are from here. It’s also home to about 30,000 Amish, who make up the bulk of its RV manufacturing workforce. Historically the Amish have worked predominantly in farming or carpentry, and without the use of electricity. However, LaGrange and Elkhart counties—which hold the third largest Amish settlement in the country—attract Amish workers to build RVs, though they are prohibited from actually driving them.

Pictured: An Amish woman adheres siding to an RV while an Amish man (image 2) works in carpentry, at the Jayco RV plant in Middlebury, Indiana. One of the many toolboxes used to manufacture Jayco RVs. Last: A worker installs gas canisters.

For more stories of cultures from around the world follow @erintrieb.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 30, 2023. May be an image of 4 people.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nicholesobecki | One of the fastest animals in the world is racing for survival. Huge reductions in their natural habitat are among the threats that have pushed the number of adult cheetahs globally to around just 7,000. The fight against the newest threat—rampant trafficking, with cheetahs being sold over social media—is being waged in an unexpected place: Somaliland, a resource-poor, self-declared autonomous republic in the Horn of Africa. Central to its efforts is the legal front, where many are pushing to increase jail sentences for traffickers. These five cubs were shown to a judge as evidence during the trial of an infamous trafficker. Moving wild animals like cheetahs to safety is a dangerous undertaking, as it requires maintaining the animal's safety and care throughout the journey. Logistical expertise, coordination with veterinary care and local authorities, and genuine respect for the animals’ well-being must be perfectly orchestrated. | That’s where @dhl_global comes in. As leaders in #logistics, DHL understands the importance of this work. Discover how their international network can help the plight of endangered big cats across the globe. https://on.natgeo.com/rescueandrewilding
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 30, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @krisgraves | Expedition Everest – Legend of the Forbidden Mountain is an impressive attraction at Disney’s Animal Kingdom Theme Park. In an area made to resemble a Tibetan village at the base of Mount Everest, we were immersed in details from the region. The village came to fruition following multiple research trips to Nepal and surrounding areas. The whole of Disney’s Animal Kingdom is the product of extensive research. The level of detail and storytelling is incredible. We also had a chance to watch the Imagineering team test techniques for creating village walls throughout Disney’s Animal Kingdom.

I was given the opportunity to capture life from behind the scenes at Walt Disney World Resort. Stay tuned for more of what makes Disney possible in the coming weeks and months. The Walt Disney Company is majority owner of National Geographic Partners. @WaltDisneyWorld @DisneyParks @natgeointhefield #DisneyWorld50
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 30, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @babaktafreshi | Under a desert moon, Death Valley National Park, California. About 280 feet (85 m) below sea level, a salt flat marks the lowest point in North America. It was a December midnight, and the moonlight shone on the honeycombed salt crust. An International Dark Sky Park, Death Valley is protected from light pollution, which makes it a favorite stargazing destination—only a few hours away from Los Angeles and Las Vegas. Explore more national parks at night @babaktafreshi. #deathvalley #earth #nightphotography #desert
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 30, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @bertiegregory | A mobula ray zooms into a school of lanternfish. These rays were previously thought to be passive filters only capable of feeding on microscopic plankton. We now know they regularly hunt small fish using the flaps on either side of their head, called cephalic lobes, to funnel fish into their huge mouths. Filmed for my new show now streaming on @disneyplus. #EpicAdventuresWithBertieGregory
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 29, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @moisessaman | At the Burkina Institute of Technology in Koudougou, Burkina Faso, designed by celebrated architect Francis Kéré and completed in 2020, poured clay forms the massive walls. A facade of eucalyptus wood creates shade. Above each classroom, a vent allows hot air to escape. It's a prime example of how traditional building materials and cooling techniques are being reclaimed by contemporary architects as the climate warms. Teachers say the cooler conditions inside the classrooms thwart fighting among students and improve concentration. For the full story, see the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 29, 2023. May be an image of 2 people.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @acacia.johnson | A cabin faces Safety Sound, Alaska. This protected lagoon near Nome has been a critical hunting, fishing, and gathering ground for Alaska Native peoples for millennia—favored for its protected waters and rich migratory bird life. Today it's globally recognized as an Important Bird Area, key to conservation efforts. Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from Alaska and beyond. #alaska #safetysound #nome
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 29, 2023. May be an image of 2 people.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @kiliiiyuyan | These portraits document a group of 21st-century "wildlings" from North America and Europe as they rediscover the primitive living skills of the Paleolithic. The Living Wild movement, spearheaded by a British expat named Lynx Vilden (on horseback), looks to change what is known as short-term wilderness survival into long-term wilderness thriving. I took these portraits with a portable backdrop shortly before heading out on a month-long excursion into the high-mountain wilderness of central Washington State—where the only material items allowed would be ones made using entirely natural materials and methods before the age of metal.

These immersion courses, where I've worked as a guest instructor, draw on hunter-gatherer methods. Today Vilden is based out of northern Norway, where participants learn how to make tools from stone or wood, use friction fire, tan hides, hunt and process meat, and gather edible berries among other activities—without any fallbacks to post-agricultural technologies. Some attendees want a deeper relationship to the landscape they live in; others seek personal alternatives to the capitalism that has taken over much of the world culturally.

It's not without controversy, as some view the movement as Indigenous appropriation. I hope both Vilden and the Indigenous peoples who hold the movement accountable will pave the way for a clearer understanding of the morality around it—and that it might bring us all closer to the land once again. Follow me for more on the human relationship with land.

This caption was updated on January 31.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 29, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | Female acorn weevils use their long snouts, or rostra, to drill into a developing acorn from multiple angles, breaking up and softening the tissue inside before boring into it once more to lay their eggs. The weevil larvae feed on the acorn as they develop. Photo taken at Waubonsie State Park in Iowa. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #weevil #acorn #insect #photography #wildlifephotography #studioportrait #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 28, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | In South Africa, each morning I rise before dawn, drawn into a land of light punctuated by the sounds and scents of the wild. Slowly the forms of lions materialize from the darkness. Frosty footprints are left in the crisp air, leaving with the warmth of the sun. From a world of mystery and darkness, the land is quickly transformed into the Africa that I love. Another day is born before my very eyes. To see more follow me @chancellordavid.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 28, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | The flowers of a cannonball tree, on long stalks projecting from the trunk, are large, beautiful, and aromatic. The tree is named for its cannonball-shaped fruit. In contrast to the flowers, the fruit releases a fetid scent at maturity, when it hits the ground and breaks open, attracting different animals. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to learn more about the organisms of the Amazon rainforest. #flowers #amazon #rainforest
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 28, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @jasperdoest | Meeting Teun Toebes (center) on assignment last year opened my eyes to the selfless, compassionate care he provides for the residents of a nursing home for adults with dementia. At only 23 years old, Toebes has been living rent free at the nursing home for more than two years, providing companionship and joy to his housemates, who are often over 50 years his senior.

Toebes’s goal is not to live the life of his housemates—that’s not possible given the age difference—but rather to contribute to dementia care in his own way. He often organizes activities, such as camping in the home’s garden. His focus on maintaining personal contact creates moments of happiness and thereby improves quality of life. “The memories my housemates have of me are based on love and friendship and not on rational memories, such as my name,” says Toebes. Recently, he moved to another nursing home because he felt that all his friends had passed away within a year or two. “People in nursing homes lead an isolated life, which makes them ill. I try to make a difference from within these homes,” he explains.

“Everyone should be entitled to an equal and inclusive society that is not diminished due to a single medical diagnosis,” he continues. “To combat the stigma often associated with dementia, it is essential to view people with this condition as human beings rather than a burden on society. Only when we recognize the individual’s humanity will they never be forgotten.”

Follow me @jasperdoest for more images about the science of longevity. #longevity #dementia #dementiaawareness
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 28, 2023. May be an image of 3 people.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Crystal River, Florida, is considered the manatee capital of the world, and Kings Bay, fed by springs, is home to the Crystal River National Wildlife Refuge, sheltering manatees year-round.

In the winter months, residents view manatees from footbridges and recognize them by the scars they bear from boat propellers. Of adult manatees, 95% have been hit by a boat once, and 25% have been hit at least 10 times. Propeller scars become unique markings and are the easiest way to identify these marine mammals. A collection scientists started in the late 1970s, the Manatee Individual Photo-Identification System database, now provides an extensive portrait of more than 3,800 manatees.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 28, 2023.

The James Webb Space Telescope is discovering distant clusters of stars that formed surprisingly early—presenting new mysteries about how the universe evolved.

Image by NASA, ESA, CSA, M. Zamani (ESA/Webb)
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 27, 2023. May be an image of text that says 'The most ancient galaxies we've ever seen are coming into view'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @kianahayeri | The Afghan government last month barred women from attending private and public universities—the latest blow to women’s rights. The Taliban administration has all but reinstituted the hard-line rule the group maintained during its first stretch in power, during the 1990s. Above: In August two university students prepare for a final exam. Second: Women leave the Kabul University campus. #kabul #afghanistan #talibantakeover #girlseducation

ph_descripcion: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | Children play in the streets of Kabul, Afghanistan, in 2009. In 2021, after two decades at war with the U.S., the Taliban resumed power. The future of the country hangs in the balance, with 70% of the populace under 25 years of age.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 27, 2023. May be an image of 3 people.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @lucalocatelliphoto | Off the coast of Italy, Nemo’s Garden is composed of six biospheres that make for a lunar, almost alien scene. It's an experiment to test whether underwater greenhouses could be an agricultural option for arid coastal countries that must put resources into desalinating water for crops.

Each dome has a platform that allows divers to partially enter the shell (as seen in the foreground). Plant cultivation is based on the hydroponic technique, whereby soil is replaced by a substrate that contains the nutrients and minerals needed for plant growth. As sunlight penetrates the humid domes, it leads to further condensation, generating the water source for the plants. Since no pests can penetrate the environment, it also doesn't require the use of chemical pesticides.

This story is part of a long-term project on circular solutions, created with the support of the Gallerie d'Italia Torino @gallerieditalia and in partnership with the Ellen MacArthur Foundation. Please follow me @lucalocatelliphoto to learn more about the solutions in our future. To read this story, go to the link in bio. #solutions #future #environment
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 27, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @nicholesobecki | Compared with humans, baboons offer researchers the ability to watch aging play out over an entire lifetime. The maximum observed life span for females is 27 years and for males, 24 years. Work done over the past half century by the Amboseli Baboon Research Project in Kenya is bringing together observational data and genetics to reveal much about the aging process—with clues for our health too. Read the full story about the science of longevity, and how to live longer and better, in the January issue and at the link in bio. To see more of my work on the interdependence of humans and nature, please follow @nicholesobecki.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 27, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio | In Georgia's Caucasus Mountains, travelers cross a turbid stream with the help of a local and his horses on a fall morning. These streams ebb and flow in daily fluctuations—as the day warms, the glaciers that feed these streams begin to melt at faster rates, transforming a morning stream into an afternoon river.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @lucasfogliaphoto | I followed psychology professor Dacher Keltner to Point Reyes National Seashore, in Northern California, as he studied how time in nature affects the human mind. From two decades of research, he concluded that the state of being in awe helps people flourish in their work and personal lives, bringing balance in a chaotic world. Follow @lucasfogliaphoto for more images and stories about people, the environment, and how we shape each other.

Photos by @christiehemmklok | Artist Jeff de Boer has been creating cat and mouse armor in his Calgary-based studio for 36 years. Each completed set of armor can take nearly 100 hours, with painstaking attention to detail. De Boer estimates he's made more than 500 suits of animal armor, meant for display only.

I was fortunate enough to watch de Boer use the “chasing” technique (second image) on a piece of gold that will be used as an accent piece on a future mouse helmet. To read more about the artist and this project, go to the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 26, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @norikohayashi_photo | Japan has the highest proportion of older adults in the world (except for the tiny principality of Monaco), and by 2050, almost 38 percent of its population will be 65 and older. The country’s life expectancy is high, but the downsides are devastating: widespread dementia, an increasingly older workforce, hamlets devoid of young people. In response, Japan is ushering in innovations to help the country cope, from community programs that ease social and physical isolation to tech innovations such as robots that help support understaffed nursing homes and farms.

(1) One of the oldest geishas still working in Japan, Ikuko Akasaka, 82, has been performing for 64 years. Her work is physically and psychologically demanding, but she continues to learn new things and polish her art. “To stay healthy is to have a desire for life and to show gratitude for others,” she says.

(2) Taira Katsuta, 89, and his wife, Ichi, 85, both have dementia. They are happily married and live by themselves in a small apartment in Tokyo.

(3) Fumie Takino, 90 (front), is the founder and oldest member of Japan Pom Pom, a senior cheer squad in Tokyo. For 26 years, Takino has practiced once a week. “It is important to be yourself and do what you want to do,“ she says, “regardless of your age.”

(4) Kazuko Kori, 89, talks to a Telenoid robot at a nursing home. A caregiver speaks through the android remotely, and patients with dementia believe they are talking to a friend or relative.

Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 25, 2023. May be an image of 2 people.
