ph_descripcion: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | At dusk, a boy makes his way down a path between houses in the Bagh-e-Qazi neighborhood of Kabul, Afghanistan, in 2009. In 2021, after two decades at war with the U.S., the Taliban resumed power, and the future of the country continues to hang in the balance. Nearly 70% of the population is under 25 years of age. Despite the challenges that lie ahead, young leaders have long played a big part in Afghanistan’s progress, and with their increasing use and access to digital spaces and social media, they're now more equipped than ever to make their voices heard.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 22, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @beverlyjoubert | Mastering an appendage as tricky as the elephant trunk comes with a steep learning curve, and this young calf on the plains of the Masai Mara in Kenya still has a way to go. Elephants are known for their expressive nature, and that’s in no small part due to their dexterous trunks and flapping ears. New research shows that up to 63,000 neurons are at work in the part of the elephant brain that controls facial movement—that’s compared to just 8,000–9,000 in humans. It’s little wonder then that the elephant trunk one of nature’s most extraordinary tools. #elephants #elephantcalf #wildlife #elephantsofinstagram
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 21, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Paleontologists Paul Sereno and Dan Vidal brush sand from an exposed sauropod femur at twilight in the Sahara. They literally stumbled upon the giant bone while walking between existing dig sites. To see more from this expedition, please visit @ladzinski.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 21, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
We sent 132 photographers on assignment. They returned with more than 2.2 million photographs. Here are some of our top pictures of the year.

📸 @jenguyton | Photographed with an infrared camera, a spotted hyena submissively lays her ears back as the clan’s dominant female towers over her in the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya,

📸 Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | Visitors ascend the spiraling 150-foot-high boardwalk at Denmark’s Camp Adventure outside of Copenhagen.

📸 @florence.goupil | The family of Indigenous Misak leader Nazaria Calambás Tunubalá mourns at her funeral in Cauca, Colombia. She was gunned down while defending a water source in a territory previously run by guerrillas.

See more from our “Pictures of the Year” issue at the link in bio.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag | Supporters of the Argentine national team celebrate its World Cup victory around, and on top of, the Malvinas Monument in Ushuaia. On December 18, Argentina won its first FIFA World Cup in 36 years. In my country, soccer is not only a sport; it is an indescribable passion that’s difficult to explain logically. Almost all Argentines grew up linked to fútbol in one way or another, and Lionel Messi is a national idol who had to overcome several battles to finally win the cup. In a very critical moment for my country—amid great environmental, social, and economic crises—this triumph means the possibility of at last celebrating something united. In a world of enormous inequality, a Latin American country has the opportunity to be victorious in front of all the rest.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 20, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @stevewinterphoto | The much beloved L.A. cougar P-22 was euthanized on Saturday, and Angelenos are mourning the loss. “There’s no cat like him,” says Steve Winter, a National Geographic photographer. It took 15 months for Winter to capture an image of P-22 under the Hollywood sign, using a camera trap. The photograph turned the cat into a celebrity and raised awareness of the plight of urban wildlife. P-22 also became an ambassador for all cougars and other creatures hemmed within scraps of disconnected habitat, cut off by massive freeways. Winter’s photographs ultimately helped create the $87 million Wallis Annenberg Wildlife Crossing, the largest in the world, which broke ground in April.

Wildlife biologists captured P-22 last week for medical evaluation after reports of erratic behavior and a collision with a car. The 12-year-old cat had suffered from various age-related conditions, but the accident sealed his fate. He couldn’t be moved to a sanctuary because of his injuries. The animal’s legacy will live on, thanks to the nonprofit Save L.A. Cougars, which continues to advocate for more corridors that connect remaining green areas. “P-22 lived for 10 years in downtown L.A. and brought together a whole community,” marvels Winter. “P-22 birthed a wildlife movement in L.A. that is only going to grow and grow.” Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 19, 2022.

The 12-year-old cat had suffered from various age-related conditions, but the accident sealed his fate. He couldn’t be moved to a sanctuary because of his injuries. The animal’s legacy will live on, thanks to the nonprofit Save L.A. Cougars, which continues to advocate for more corridors that connect remaining green areas. “P-22 lived for 10 years in downtown L.A. and brought together a whole community,” marvels Winter. “P-22 birthed a wildlife movement in L.A. that is only going to grow and grow.” Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 19, 2022.

The steady increase in opioid overdose deaths across the U.S.—which more than doubled among teens in just two years—has heightened debate over the role of naloxone in the front lines of American addiction.

Photograph by Jane Barlow, PA Images via Getty Image
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 19, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Documenting climate change can sometimes leave little room for optimism. That’s why Kiliii Yüyan, one of our 2022 Photographers of the Year, makes it his mission to highlight the solutions that are already out there and in practice by Native communities around the world. “Eighty percent of the world’s existing land biodiversity is on territories managed by Indigenous peoples, who make up just 5 percent of the global population,” he says. “Nearly all of that territory encompasses people making a living with wildlife. This is where my hope lives.”

📸 @kiliiiyuyan | Cousins Berthe Simigaq and Nellie Simigaq push strollers across the sea ice on their way to annual dogsled races in Qaanaaq, Greenland. The races are the biggest events in town and reflect the important relationship that Inughuit, or northern Greenlandic Inuit, have with dog teams—the main means of transportation here during much of the year.

📸 @gleb_raygorodetsky | Kiliii Yüyan stands on the back of a dogsled while photographing a story on Indigenous land stewardship in Greenland with writer Gleb Raygorodetsky.

Learn more about Kiliii and our other Photographers of the Year at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 19, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @timlaman | Today’s surprise in the Borneo rainforest is viper love. A male Bornean green pit viper (Tropidolaemus subannulatus) snuggles on the much larger female (they're actually the same species), which I can only assume is a courtship behavior. There’s always something new to see every day in the forest. I’m on assignment in Gunung Palung National Park, West Kalimantan, Indonesia, documenting the biodiversity of this key refuge. Tune in @TimLaman for more from the field. #viper #snake #borneo #indonesia #gunungpalungnationalpark
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 19, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @laurakmorton | Over the last few years, filmgoers across the United States have been revitalizing a classic American pastime: the drive-in movie theater. Down from a high of about 4,000 in the late 1950s, an estimated 330 drive-ins are still in operation in the country. And the pandemic brought in new customers. In Kane, Pennsylvania, the Kane Family Drive-In Theatre has been in operation since 1952. When it went up for sale, a local family bought it with the goal of keeping it running for the enjoyment of the town and future generations. For more photographs of people and places, follow along @laurakmorton.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 18, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | Sand cats like Sven, as he's called, are master hunters. These felines skulk close to the ground, listening for prey burrowing underground. At the first hint of a potential meal, the sand cat will begin digging rapidly to expose and capture prey. While they feed primarily on small rodents, this species can also successfully capture hares, birds, spiders, and even venomous snakes. Photo taken @chattanoogazoo. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #cat #sandcat #feline #hunter #wildlifephotography #wildlife #studioportrait #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 18, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @estherhorvath | In an old military bunker, scientists trace the rise—and sometimes the fall—of chemical pollutants in an industrial country.

Till Weber manages the German Environmental Specimen Bank, where cryo-storage tanks hold 400,000 vials of blood and urine, annually collected over four decades from German volunteers on behalf of the German Environment Agency.

It's part of the federal ministry's effort to monitor exposure to chemicals like lead, mercury, and plasticizers. The project traces which substances have accumulated at potentially dangerous levels, and considers whether bans and regulations of some of those substances have been effective. To read the story, go to the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 18, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stephenwilkes | A Day to Night image of J Bar L Ranch in Melville, Montana, from the September cover story on America's wild lands.

Located near Yellowstone National Park, the ranch aims to raise cattle while also conserving habitat for pronghorn, moose, trumpeter swans, and sage grouse, to name a few. Fences have been modified to allow wildlife to cross the ranch. Herds are bunched and moved frequently to mimic buffalo, whose tread shaped these grasslands. The bulls in this scene—assembled from 60 photos—graze before mountains known as the Crazies, as time passes from daybreak to sunset to starlit night.

I was deeply impressed by the ranch hands. They’re the real deal. Their whole being, their whole life, is connected to this land.

In my Day to Night series, landscapes are portrayed from a fixed camera angle over the course of a full day. A select group of these images are blended into a single composite. To see more from my travels near and far, follow me @stephenwilkes. #montana #ranch #jbarlmontana #cattle #daytonight
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 17, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | Iranians are probably the most hospitable people I have ever met. Anyone who has traveled to their country will tell you the same. Walking around the market, in the streets, or in the fields, you will inevitably be invited by random strangers to come for lunch or stay overnight in their homes, just because. Such kindness has taught me a lot: When I have visitors, I like to treat them as I’ve been treated in my travels there—but it can sometimes be challenging! Here are a series of kind souls we’ve met and who’ve hosted us during a trip across Iran by train, with @paleyography for National Geographic, in 2018. Read the full story at the link in bio. For more insights into our world, please follow @paleyphoto #iran
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 17, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
For Aji Styawan, one of our 2022 Photographers of the Year, climate change has taken hold in his backyard—literally. Living nine miles from the coastline in Java, Indonesia, Styawan has made it his mission to tell the stories of climate change that he sees on a daily basis. “People have to understand,” he says. “If this is happening anywhere, it’s a big, big problem to everyone.”

📸 @ajistyawan | On a low coastal land in the province of Central Java, villagers from Timbulsloko prepare to add mud to their cemetery to raise it above the high tide line. Before adding mud, they mark the locations of the graves with bamboo sticks.

📸 Ahmad Samsudin | Styawan stands in tidal floodwater to photograph resident Kusmiyatun on her terrace. Her home faces a main road on the north coast of Central Java, where sinking land, coastal erosion, and rising seas result in extreme flooding.

Learn more about Aji and our other Photographers of the Year at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 16, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio | Medieval villages punctuated by stone defense towers, called koshkis, dot the fertile high-elevation valleys of Europe’s tallest mountain range, the Caucasus. Svaneti, a region in northern Georgia bordering Russia, has a long history of invasions: Persians, Mongols, Turks, and, in contemporary times, Russians. Because of the rugged surroundings, walls were seen as impractical; koshki stonemasonry came into being starting in the ninth century A.D.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 16, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @sofia_jaramillo5 | Alyssa Gonzalez stands for a portrait during a women’s mountain biking festival in Sedona, Arizona. It's part of a series I call Women Who Roam, for the @thisisroam attendees endeavoring to change the face of the cycling industry.

Gonzalez is a professional cyclist and works as a DEI (diversity, equity, inclusion) consultant. She's an advocate for gender diversity in cycling and a community builder focused on creating opportunities and experiences for women of color and others in marginalized communities.

“As a queer woman of color, the act of just showing up on the trails on my bike is radical," she says, "and I try to pass that message on and the joy of cycling to all folks I meet."

"Biking has become a huge part of my life. It’s how I move my body, exercise, and process. It’s been the main way that I’ve found more diverse and inclusive communities to be part of. I’ve learned a lot about what I can do with my body and mind while on a bike, and it’s transferred to my everyday life. The bike has made me stronger, more confident, social, aware, and gritty.”

I asked what changes she’d like to see in the outdoor community. “More of an attitude that everyone has a space in the outdoors and in nature, and less of a gatekeeping mentality," she says. "I would love to see more respect and acknowledgment for Indigenous folks and their land. Indigenous sovereignty and the land back movement are so important for our climate, the outdoors, and the communities of Native folks in this country and beyond.”

For more images of women in outdoor sports and cycling follow me @sofia_jaramillo5. #cycling #mountainbiking #womenonbikes
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 15, 2022.

We sent 132 photographers on assignment. They returned with more than 2.2 million photographs. Here are some of our top pictures of the year.

📸 @carstenpeter | The Cumbre Vieja volcanic ridge erupts on La Palma, one of Spain's Canary Islands. The eruption lasted for three months, bulldozing roads, more than 2,800 buildings, and 864 acres of farmland.

📸 @mattabbottphoto | Rangers hunt turtles on land they manage as traditional Aboriginal owners in the Warddeken Indigenous Protected Area, in northern Australia.

📸 @alecegarra | Macaws perch on a rooftop, waiting to be fed by locals in Caracas, Venezuela. The birds have proliferated in Venezuela’s capital city over the past few decades because of the pet trade.

See more from our Pictures of the Year issue at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 14, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @amivitale | Ever since the last male northern white rhino died in 2018 (and the two remaining females are too old to reproduce), scientists have been working on in vitro solutions in an attempt to resurrect the functionally extinct species.

Now there's breaking news: The @biorescue_project has produced primordial germ cells from northern white rhino stem cells—a world’s first for large mammals. Primordial germ cells are embryonic precursors of sperm and eggs that pass on genetic and epigenetic information from one generation to the next. This paves the way to produce functional gametes (eggs and sperm) from the preserved tissue of other northern white rhinos. If successful, this would boost the availability and genetic diversity of embryos and become a cornerstone for saving the northern white rhinoceros.

The @biorescue_project has already successfully created 22 embryos from oocytes harvested from Fatu, as one of the rhinos is named. This latest development is one more huge step in saving this species—and potentially many others—from certain extinction.

The @biorescue_project is a team of scientists and conservationists from @leibnizizw @OlPejeta conservancy @safariparkdvurkralove @kenyawildlifeservice and Wildlife Research and Training Institute (WRTI). Follow @biorescue_project and @amivitale for more information, including how to help.

#Conservation #Kenya #StopPoaching #NorthernWhiteRhinos #rhinos
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 14, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | A family of endangered François’ langurs @theomahazoo. Found in southern China and northeastern Vietnam, these monkeys are good jumpers, with a long tail that they use for balance and long, hairless fingers that are used for gripping. When they’re born, infants are bright orange for the first three or four months, allowing them to be highly visible in the thick forest to the multiple females that will care for them, a process known as allomothering. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #langur #francois #monkey #primate #animals #wildlife #studioportrait #familyportrait #animalphotography #wildlifephotography #photography #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 13, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone | Winged goddesses protect each corner of Tutankhamun’s sarcophagus—which, along with his mummy, remains in his tomb in the Valley of the Kings, in Luxor, Egypt. Other Egyptian royals are known to have been buried in the valley, but their graves haven't been located, raising a tantalizing question: Are there more tombs like Tut’s to be discovered?

Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | I’ve had a lot of time this past week to sit and think. I’ve been playing hide-and-seek with an Arabian leopard cub in Taif, Saudi Arabia. She’s shy, and something deep inside me hopes that will always be the case.

I’m not a wildlife photographer. I don’t have the patience to sit for hours, days, or months in order to get that shot. What’s brought me here is the birth of this cub and the significance of it in terms of human-wildlife coexistence. I’m here to bear witness to the reinstatement of wildlife and ecosystems that man’s very presence has previously destroyed. A powerful symbol of the restoration and regeneration of the country’s natural landscape is the Arabian leopard. Amal (“hope”) is one of two cubs born recently at the breeding center here in Taif. The goal is that, in the not too distant future, she will contribute to the rewilding of this landscape when these truly majestic cats are reintroduced back into their rightful position as apex predators. A lot of work will need to be done before that happens, but what we see here is an enormously bright light by which progress can be illuminated. To see more follow me @chancellordavid.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 12, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Michael Yamashita @yamashitaphoto | Here’s a throwback to one of the most popular and strangest photographs I've posted—I call it morning stretch. In China it's common to see older people practicing tai chi, exercising, and stretching in parks around the country. In fact, most seniors have not exercised seriously until after retirement and are in better shape than the younger generation.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 12, 2022.

Please follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images, primarily from the Nordic countries. #Adventdalen #Norway #Spitsbergen #Svalbard #blue #landscapephotography

ph_descripcion: Photo by @davidemonteleonestudio | Medyka, Poland, March 2022. Refugees from Ukraine wait at the border to board a train to Przemysl, where they would receive assistance before moving on to other Polish and European towns. Follow @davidemonteleonestudio for more.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 11, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @sofia_jaramillo5 | A rancher in eastern Washington State adjusts a harness. Ranchers not only help their animals to graze but do everything from applying topical medications to prevent parasites, lice, and ticks and vaccinating them against common diseases, to castrating and branding cattle. Multigenerational ranching and farming operations are scattered throughout the state. For more images from the rural Pacific Northwest, follow @sofia_jaramillo5. #ranching #washington #PNW
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 10, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Mattias A. Klum @mattiasklumofficial | Melting natural sculptures of ice in Grey Lake at Torres del Paine National Park in Chile. While taking a series of images here, I went a bit too far, and my tripod lost its grip. To avoid jeopardizing the camera gear, I fell in instead—quite a brisk experience! My great friend and assistant at the time, Lars-Magnus, helped pull me out of the ice-cold water. The amazing blue color in the back is caused by the ice absorbing red light, or long wavelengths, and scattering back and transmitting blue light, or short wavelengths.

Photographed on assignment. To see more of our projects, please visit @mattiasklumofficial. #torresdelpaine #chile #livingthedream #protectbiodiversity #mattiasklum #chile #conservation #patagonia @mattiasklumofficial @natgeo
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 10, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | Four little owls (Athene noctua) perch on top of a rock at sunrise in Castilla–La Mancha, Spain. In the middle of summer, these chicks stay together, close to their fathers, exploring the surroundings of the nest and learning to survive in a hostile habitat. By summer’s end, they will all separate from one another, looking for their own territory. These sedentary birds inhabit northern Africa and parts of Europe and Asia. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to see more little creatures. #owl #littleowl #bird
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 09, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @stevewinterphoto | The U.S. Senate passed the Big Cat Public Safety Act, now headed to President Biden for signature. The act prohibits both owning lions, tigers, and other big cats (including hybrids such as ligers) as pets and public contact with them, including petting and taking selfies with cubs. Commercial breeding that has supplied cubs to lucrative “tiger playtime” tourist attractions at roadside zoos must now come to an end.

@sharon.guynup and I spent two years investigating this wildlife trade for National Geographic. Our reporting revealed that most cubs in the U.S.—where captive tigers outnumber those in the wild—were born in "tiger mills," pulled from their mothers at birth. Females churn out back-to-back litters, compared with one every two years in the wild. Many cubs were ill-fed, inbred, and in poor health with no vet care. Unknown numbers died. Some were sold and illegally trafficked to other states even before their eyes opened. At three months, cubs reach their “expiration date”—too big and dangerous to pet—and are discarded. The crisis was a result of lax USDA oversight and no federal regulations.

This law not only protects captive cats but also the public and first responders from these large, dangerous predators.

But it doesn't end with U.S. policy. There is more to be done on tiger "farming" in China, Thailand, Laos, and Vietnam, where cats are raised for the high-end trade in tiger skin decor and tiger bone "wine." Demand for these and other products drives poaching of the world’s last 4,000 wild tigers.

This bill—which was first introduced 10 years ago and passed unanimously—highlights the power of photography, storytelling, and persistence. To see our December 2019 cover story, which was sent to all members of Congress, read the link in bio. #bigcatvoices
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 08, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Lightning rains down from the dark clouds of a supercell storm system high over the panhandle of northern Texas. Storm cells of this magnitude are responsible for natural disasters ranging from tornados to wildfires to flooding. The landscape and ecosystem here have a long history of such battery, adapted to benefit from the life-giving rain and wind-driven pollination that take place during storms like this. To see more images of storm chasing, please visit @ladzinski.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 08, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @estherhorvath | Some 400,000 specimens from German citizens, collected over four decades and stored in an old military bunker, trace the rise—and sometimes the fall—of chemical pollutants in an industrial country.

At the German Environmental Specimen Bank, cryo-storage tanks hold thousands of vials of blood and urine, annually collected from volunteers on behalf of the German Environment Agency. Inside the tanks, liquid nitrogen keeps the samples in a deep freeze. The vials are stored in racks that sit in a cloud of gaseous nitrogen above the liquid.

It's part of the federal ministry's effort to monitor exposure to chemicals like lead, mercury, and plasticizers. The project traces which substances have accumulated at potentially dangerous levels, and considers whether bans and regulations of some of those substances have been effective. To read the story, go to the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 07, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @acacia.johnson | A floatplane withstands a winter blizzard at Lake Hood Seaplane Base in Anchorage, Alaska. With only 20% of Alaska accessible by road, planes provide essential services to dozens of its remote communities—as well as a way for people to access Alaska's wilderness.

The world's busiest seaplane base, Lake Hood is home to over 1,000 aircraft that use the facilities year-round. During winter months, when floatplanes such as this one are taken out of the water, the frozen lake surface is maintained as a runway for aircraft equipped with skis.

Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from Alaska and beyond. #alaska #aviation #airplane #winter
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 07, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone | A team of geneticists led by Yehia Gad (second from left) examines the mummy of an unidentified boy in the tomb of Pharaoh Amenhotep II. A pioneer in the DNA analysis of ancient mummies, Gad is studying samples from King Tutankhamun and his extended family, looking for clues to their ancestral ties and genetic maladies.

Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 07, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @davidemonteleonestudio | The Pamir mountain landscape on the Afghanistan-Tajikistan border, 2016. Tajikistan has been at the crossroads of civilizations for over a thousand years—and occupied by Russians, Turks, Arabs, Uzbeks, Chinese, and Genghis Khan and the Mongols. In more recent years, the country served as a key staging area and supply route for U.S. and NATO operations against the Taliban. Like other Central Asian nations, Tajikistan has been heavily dependent on Russia for economic aid, security assistance, and labor markets. Follow me @davidemonteleonestudio for more.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 06, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @erintrieb | In August 2021, when the Taliban took control of Afghanistan, a way of life with freedom and civil rights that many Afghans cherished for two decades was turned upside down. This was the case for one women’s rights activist, whose name is being withheld out of concern for her safety. The fundamentalist regime cracked down on women-led protests—often arresting, beating, and kidnapping those who marched in the streets. But for this activist, who says her father was murdered by the Taliban for being an educator in her village, protesting, no matter how dangerous, was a matter of personal justice. She has since fled the country, stating she’s received death threats and is being targeted by the Taliban. She hopes to immigrate to the U.S. or Europe but struggles to find visa opportunities for her family, who are still in Afghanistan.

At a family wedding celebration, she (with mask) checks emails and text messages from colleagues and later takes a break to dance with a friend.

Follow @erintrieb for more stories from Afghanistan.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 06, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | Few species love trees as much as two-toed sloths do. These sloths do everything in the trees, from eating and sleeping to mating and giving birth. While they will move from tree to tree, individuals rarely stray far from the general area where they were born, traveling no more than 120 feet (37 m) in a day. Trips to the ground are typically reserved for bathroom breaks, which happen only once a week. This one-month old was photographed @centroderescateamazonico. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #sloth #baby #animal #mammal #wildlife #photography #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 06, 2022.

After the attack on Pearl Harbor, the mini-sub washed ashore in Hawaii in December 1941. Then came the fight over who’d get to keep it.

Photograph via U.S. Naval History and Heritage Command
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 05, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @alessandro.cinque | A medical team prepares an alpaca for surgery. I spent three days at Peru's Quimsachata Research and Production Center, home to the largest genetic reserve of alpaca breeds. With state-of-the-art technology, the center is attempting to combat the effects of climate change on alpacas, which are indigenous to Peru and integral to everyday life. Changes in weather patterns have impacted their reproduction and survival.

Through in-vitro insemination, the center is attempting to breed more resilience in the genes of the animals and improve their reproductive capacity. They're also targeting prevention and treatment of diseases that adversely affect the productivity of camelids. This female alpaca is being prepared for a laparatomy, which allows researchers to explore the reproductive organs and do a molecular aspiration. To see more of my work, please follow @alessandro.cinque.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 05, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | On an afternoon in 2020, I went on a popular Qatari outing to an area known as Sealine, just south of Doha. Crossing sand dunes in SUVs, friends and family often meet up for sunset picnics overlooking the Persian Gulf, a respite from city life. For more glimpses of our world, follow me @paleyphoto. #qatar

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @lucalocatelliphoto | Off the coast of Italy, near the village of Noli, researchers are testing a new kind of agriculture—underwater greenhouses. They hope it could be a solution for arid coastal countries, which must invest in a costly process of desalinating water for crops. These plastic domes—called Nemo's Garden—shelter biospheres containing plant seeds, fans, hydroponic equipment, and a bit of starter water—condensation takes care of the rest.

Each of the five biospheres is an independent environment. Light is provided by the penetrating sun, but when needed a ring (center) gives an extra boost. A small fan keeps air circulating. The garden is monitored remotely by a crew on shore.

This story is part of a long-term project on circular solutions, created with the support of the Museum of Photography Gallerie d'Italia Torino @gallerieditalia in partnership with the Ellen McArthur Foundation. Read the full story at the link in bio. Please follow me @lucalocatelliphoto to learn more about the making of the future. #solutions #future #environment
ph_atributos: Photo shared by National Geographic on December 04, 2022 tagging @nemos_garden_official.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @stephenwilkes | City Park in New Orleans was part of the “America the Beautiful” cover story in the September issue.

The hundred-acre (40 ha) Wisner tract, a former golf course wrecked by Hurricane Katrina, is within the boundaries of City Park and is being restored to a more natural state. With diverse habitats—lagoon, swamp, marsh, live oak forest, meadowland—it’s a retreat for birds such as egrets and geese, city dwellers from all walks of life, and just about every breed of dog that you could imagine. Restoring degraded urban spaces and providing equitable access to nature are key goals in conservation’s next phase.

I photographed from two scissor lifts at a height of about 60 feet (18 m), revealing the skyline and Superdome, less than five miles away. I took 2,012 photographs and used 43 to create this image.

In the Day to Night series, cityscapes and landscapes are portrayed from a fixed camera angle, capturing fleeting moments of humanity and nature as light passes in front of the lens over the course of a full day. A select group of these images are blended into a single composite. To see more from my travels near and far, follow me @stephenwilkes. #natgeo #nola #park #daytonight #america #beautiful
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 04, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @timlaman | A Bornean horned frog (Megophrys nasuta) is master of camouflage in the leaf litter of the rainforest. Can you spot it in the second image? Horns help it blend in with the pointed leaf tips. This cryptic frog was high on my list of species I wanted to find as I document the biodiversity of Borneo’s rainforest in Gunung Palung National Park for the magazine. Follow along @timlaman as I share behind the scenes coverage from my shoot. #frog #borneohornedfrog #borneo #indonesia #kalimantan #gunungpalungnationalpark #onassignment
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 03, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone | A 3,200-year-old statue of Ramses the Great dominates the atrium of the new Grand Egyptian Museum, popularly known as the GEM, on the outskirts of Cairo. Two decades in the making at an estimated cost of more than a billion dollars, the facility brings together, for the first time, nearly all 5,000-plus artifacts from King Tutankhamun’s tomb.

Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 03, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @amivitale | Najma studies by candlelight in the single room she shares with her 10 siblings in Kenya's Loita Hills area. She passed exams necessary to obtain entrance to a county high school. When Kenya enacted a law that made primary education free, enrollment rates increased to 84 percent. However, only one in five girls make it to their eighth year. This high dropout rate is a result of early marriage, poverty, and other factors. Investing in girls' education has profound impacts. To learn more, follow @forthegood and @amivitale. #girls #letgirlsgirlearn #education #schools
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 02, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Read the full story at the link in bio.

New clues from the day the dinosaurs died. A mysterious ancient human tooth. Primordial galaxies. See how the past year expanded our knowledge of the cosmos and our own backyard.

Photograph by Max Alguilera-Hellweg, National Geographic
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 02, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @beverlyjoubert | A tender moment is captured in Kenya’s Masai Mara. A giraffe mother’s job isn’t easy. Before young calves grow to reach the title of world’s tallest animal, they are vulnerable to a range threats, and in predator-dense areas, up to 50 percent of them are likely to fall to a hungry lion or hyena. To give them time to grow and develop in preparation for entry into a dangerous world, mother giraffes carry their young in the womb for 15 months. After that, the mothers’ expert ability to hide their young and defensive kicks when danger draws near help nudge the odds of survival upward. #giraffe #giraffecalf #wildlife
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 02, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @williamodaniels | Ukraine, 2013. Overgrown and abandoned buildings in the town of Pripyat, which was evacuated following the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear reactor disaster. Follow me on @williamodaniels for more stories around the world.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 01, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @erintrieb | A women’s rights activist adjusts her niqab, which she wears to hide her identity in this image.

In August 2021, when the Taliban took control of Afghanistan, a way of life with freedoms and civil rights that many Afghans cherished for two decades was turned upside down. The Taliban cracked down, arresting, beating, and kidnapping women rights’ activists. The woman pictured here says she has received death threats and was beaten by the Taliban with the butt of an AK-47 rifle for participating in public protests. She has since fled the country, hoping to immigrate to the U.S. or Europe, but struggles to find visa opportunities for herself and her family, who remain in Afghanistan. For more stories on Afghanistan follow @erintrieb.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 01, 2022.

A polar bear sleeping in a field of flowers, a fish that looks like seaweed, and leopards courting in the mist: These 21 images are our favorite animal pictures of the year.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @krisgraves | The Shaman of Songs greets visitors to the Na'vi River Journey attraction at Disney’s Animal Kingdom Theme Park. In 1963, Walt Disney debuted modern Audio-Animatronics technology, which has since become a staple across Disney parks. We visited a training area to view an eight-foot (2.4-meter) A-100 Audio-Animatronics figure and learned about the history of hand development. The team was busy but kind enough to give us a preview of what they were working on. I felt like a kid in a candy store.

I was given the opportunity to capture life from behind the scenes at Walt Disney World Resort. Stay tuned for more of what makes Disney possible in the coming weeks and months. The Walt Disney Company is majority owner of National Geographic Partners. @WaltDisneyWorld @DisneyParks @natgeointhefield #DisneyWorld50
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 30, 2022.

The next total lunar eclipse will be visible in Australia on September 8, 2025. #LunarEclipse #BloodMoon #LunarEclipse2022 #Nature #Moon #Landscape #Naarm #Victoria #Australia

ph_descripcion: Photo by @alessandro.cinque | In Ecuador, mining has only recently risen as a strategic sector, and some activists say it may be encroaching on Indigenous territories and protected areas. Here, children play outside the city of Loja, on the grounds of the Basílica del Cisne, a pilgrimage shrine. This land, despite being a place of worship, has been concessioned to a mining company by the government, according to local press and NGOs. The children wait for their parents, pilgrims who journeyed to the site. To see more of my work, please follow me @alessandro.cinque.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 29, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @beverlyjoubert | What a catch! With so many dramatic predator-prey battles playing out across the sprawling landscapes of Botswana’s Okavango Delta, hunters of the winged kind can be easily overlooked. But cast your eyes (and camera) skyward and you’ll soon appreciate why they shouldn’t be. No shortage of skill, agility, and precision was spent to acquire this prized frog meal. Colorful beauty aside, the woodland kingfisher is a sight to behold as it swoops down on unsuspecting prey. #birdlovers #kingfisher #birdwatchers
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 29, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Just south of Salzburg and tucked within the Alps, Eisriesenwelt is the world's biggest ice cave. A tour with veteran guide Siegi Kaml (pictured) ends with visitors arriving at a frozen lake inside a chamber known as the Eispalast, or “ice palace.” But as temperatures rise, the volume of ice in many caves is shrinking. And in some, the ice is no longer perennial: It's melted by rain and warm air that infiltrate the caves. In the article "When the Magic Melts," in the October issue, I document the contributions of scientists—and tour guides—as they work against the clock in this rapidly disappearing landscape.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 29, 2022.

Buried during the Stone Age, this woman once roamed the forests of northern Sweden. Now archaeologists have reconstructed her face.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @renaeffendiphoto | Mardin, a city in southeastern Turkey, dates back to Mesopotamian civilization and was later part of the Byzantine, Seljuk, and Ottoman Empires. At an elevation of 3,450 feet (1,051 m), the city sits on the edge of a highland overlooking a vast plateau that expands to northern Syria and Iraq. Mardin, Aleppo, and Mosul have been part of a diverse fabric of Syriac, Arab, Turkish, and Kurdish cultures. Today, with Aleppo and Mosul both damaged in brutal wars, Mardin stands as witness to this important historic and multi-cultural heritage. #mardin #turkey #culture #history #heritage #syria #iraq
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 28, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames, words by National Geographic Explorer paula_kahumbu | Some local pastoralists have given up trying to save their cows. “I might as well let them just die,” said one cattle owner, who has been reduced from a millionaire in livestock to a recipient of hay donations. Three consecutive failed rainy seasons have turned the land to desert and left livestock and wildlife with almost nothing to eat. The Kenyan government has declared an emergency and, together with the private sector, started provisioning some communities with food, water, and hay. That might ease the pain in the short term, but it could be too little, too late. The drought was predicted, but its catastrophic impact has surprised everyone. As successive droughts bring deeper and deeper consequences, this fragile land is reaching a breaking point as the ecological resilience is destroyed. Unless major changes in land management are implemented soon, the proud pastoralist culture and tourism industry of the region could be lost forever. With support from the National Geographic Society @insidenatgeo.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 28, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag | Portrait of José Catricura, who holds a baby goat. He belongs to the Mapuche community in the Huilliche area of Argentina, where the Mapuche are the largest group of Indigenous people. Follow me at @lujanag to learn more about this and other stories from my Patagonian homeland.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 28, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @mattiasklumofficial | A painted dog chews on the bones of a young kudu in Botswana’s Mombo Camp. African painted dogs are very social, and packs frequently share food and assist ill or weak family members. Intricate social interactions are common, and the dogs communicate by touch, vocalizations, and actions. Painted dogs are endangered and faced with shrinking room to roam in their African home. They are also quite susceptible to diseases spread by domestic animals.

Please check out @mattiasklumofficial for more images of endangered animals and environments. #doglovers #protectbiodiversity #botswana #predator #africa #painteddog #conservation @thephotosociety @alexandrovklumofficial
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 27, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @acacia.johnson | Inuit elder Peugatuk Ettuk’s dog team pulls a sledge across the sea ice near Arctic Bay, Nunavut. In this part of the eastern Canadian Arctic, the Inuit have used dog teams for travel and hunting for millennia. Although most people now rely on snowmobiles for transportation, Ettuk said he still preferred the companionship of his dogs—and pointed out that unlike snowmobiles, dog teams don’t break down.

Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from the Arctic and beyond. #arctic #sleddogs #winter #nunavut #baffinisland
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 27, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @gerdludwig | Visible from the 75th floor of Abu Dhabi Plaza—the tallest tower in Astana, Kazakhstan—an expanse of grasslands surrounds the glistening city. With its unique location on the world’s largest steppe, Astana is susceptible to extreme weather, sometimes resulting in striking views.

Since 1997, this once small town has risen from a forsaken landscape and post-Soviet rubble, transforming into a futuristic city. After replacing Almaty as the country's capital, Astana grew from having 320,000 inhabitants to over 1.2 million.

Before restoring the capital's name to Astana earlier this year, President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev had renamed it Nursultan to honor outgoing Nursultan Nazarbayev, who announced his resignation in 2019 after serving as the first and only president of modern Kazakhstan for almost 30 years. Since its founding as a Russian military outpost in 1824, Astana has undergone several naming iterations—in fact, the city holds the Guinness World Record for most name changes.
#NurSultan #Astana #Kazakhstan
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 27, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone | At the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, Salima Ikram examines a tiny coffin made for a mummified shrew. “For the ancient Egyptians, no animal was too small to be ignored,” says the professor of Egyptology at the American University in Cairo, “and each occupied a very particular place in the cosmos.”

Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 26, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | Native to Madagascar, tomato frogs belong to a variety of habitats across the northeastern part of the island. They've been found to adapt well to urban environments and are spotted in drainage ditches and on farmland as often as they're seen within rainforests. Their only “must-haves” include places to burrow and slow-moving or stagnant water where they can lay their eggs. Photo taken @theomahazoo. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #frog #tomato #tomatofrog #amphibian #animal #wildlife #animalphotography #wildlifephotography #studioportrait #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 25, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Michael Yamashita @yamashitaphoto | Wuqiao County, in Hebei Province, is known as the birthplace of Chinese acrobatics—a history dating back some two thousand years to the Han Dynasty. The county is located on the Grand Canal, which historically enabled acrobatic troops to travel north to Beijing and Tianjin and south to Hangzhou and Yangzhou for performances—and still does today. Dozens of internationally recognized schools teach acrobatic skills to locals and foreigners alike. Three-year-olds are among the youngest students at the Changfa Acrobatic School. Its program includes tumbling, juggling, contortion, and a basic education, which costs $150 a year for tuition and room and board. #acrobat #tradition
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 25, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @sofia_jaramillo5 | Idaho is the 14th largest state by total area and has more than 25,000 farms that account for nearly 20 percent of the state’s economic output, including potatoes, wheat, sugar beets, and more. When I drive around my home in southeast Idaho, I love seeing the juxtaposition of the fall leaves and the farmers gathering their crops after a long summer. For more images from Idaho and around the world, follow me @sofia_jaramillo5. #farming #agriculture #idaho
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 25, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @sarahyltonphoto | In a remote region of northern Ontario, Canada, Ana Moonias plays on land belonging to the Neskantaga First Nation while her family is off hunting partridge. Neskantaga is connected only by air from Thunder Bay or by ice roads—frozen rivers and waterways that are maintained for winter travel. The region is located near the "ring of fire," an area known to be rich in deposits of copper, platinum, chromite, and nickel—resources the Ontario government is eager to capitalize on. For more on this and other stories, follow me @sarahyltonphoto. #Canada #Indigenous #environment
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 24, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @timlaman | The white-bearded gibbon of Borneo is an amazing acrobat of the treetops. A full complement of biodiversity exists at Gunung Palung National Park, a healthy refuge of lowland rainforest in Indonesia’s West Kalimantan Province. White-bearded gibbons are one of the endangered species that thrive here. I captured these shots of a female with baby, and of a juvenile feeding high in the canopy of a strangler fig tree, from a blind in an adjacent tree early one morning. Follow along on my adventures exploring this amazing park @timlaman. #gibbon #gunungpalungnationalpark #borneo #indonesia #rainforest
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 24, 2022.

Increasing your intake of zinc and vitamins C and D during winter isn’t a magic bullet. Here’s what the science says about the most commonly touted interventions.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Drunken Forest is a cave in Mulu National Park on the Malaysian island of Borneo. It was discovered in 1984 on an expedition led by the British. There is something unusual about Drunken Forest, as you can see. In certain parts of the cave, the stalagmites lean. On first impression, they look like they were formed at an angle, but that's not the case. It's thought that an earthquake many years ago tilted the stalagmites. Here, researchers Gina Moseley from the University of Innsbruck and Nele Meckler of Bergen University take a drip-water sample from a stalagmite.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 23, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @stephenwilkes | I was recently in British Columbia, on Chilko Lake, the traditional territory of the Xeni Gwet’in First Nations, scouting for a new photography site, when we witnessed a mother and a few grizzly bear cubs playing and gorging on what looked like a limitless supply of salmon. In the fall, millions of salmon return to the lake to spawn at the Chilko River's mouth, creating an incredibly rich food source for the bears. I’m looking forward to sharing more images from this remarkable experience. Special thanks to the incredible team @bear.camp for the amazing support. To see more from my travels near and far follow me @stephenwilkes @insidenatgeo. #bc #bears #canada #natgeo #chilkolake
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 23, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @estherhorvath | Some 400,000 specimens from German citizens, collected over four decades and stored in an old military bunker, trace the rise—and sometimes the fall—of chemical pollutants in an industrial country.

At the German Environmental Specimen Bank, Dominik Lermen stands among cryo-storage tanks that hold thousands of vials of blood and urine. Lerman leads the team that collects samples from volunteers every year and stores them here on behalf of the German Environment Agency.

It's part of a federal ministry's effort to “to systematically monitor and analyze human exposure to chemicals like lead, mercury, plasticizers, and others,” Lermen says. The project traces which substances have accumulated at potentially dangerous levels, and considers whether bans and regulations of some of those substances have been effective. Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 22, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | In the highlands of Ecuador live one of the most emblematic mammals of the Andes, the vicuña. This herbivore has adapted to the region’s high altitude, serving as important seed dispersers in the nutrient cycle and, through its dung, fertilizers of soil. Its population is now stable in Ecuador, but in the past, it had disappeared from the wild and was reintroduced with animals from Peru, Bolivia, and Chile. The vicuña belongs to the same genus as the alpaca, but the former is still wild while the latter has been domesticated.

Follow me @javier_aznar_photography for more images and stories about Ecuador. #ecuador #vicuna #wildlife
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 22, 2022.

Rising out of the desert, It's known for its psychedelic dance parties and outlandish art installations. For more images, follow me @dina_litovsky.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | The fastest land animal on Earth and a masterful hunter, cheetahs can hit speeds on flat ground that exceed 60 mph. Even so, the success rate for their hunts is just shy of 60%. I photographed this one in the Masai Mara—it speaks volumes about life in the wild.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 21, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @gabrielegalimbertiphoto and Juri De Luca | Fossils of long-extinct creatures aren’t just for museums. Today they’re in homes and businesses, as wealthy collectors indulge in a controversial hobby. Here, 11-year-old Luke Phipps sits atop a Triceratops fossil—still in a plaster “jacket” used for carefully transporting a fossil from the field to a lab—with Chris Morrow, owner of CK Preparations, a commercial fossil company in Montana. Luke found the fossil while digging with his father, Clayton Phipps, a rancher and amateur paleontologist known as the dinosaur cowboy. #dinosaurs #dino #dinosaur #collection #triceratops
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 20, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Michaela Skovranova @mishkusk | The eastern gray kangaroo, found in Australia's southeastern state of Victoria, can often be seen in grasslands and shrubs—or hopping through a golf course, grazing during dusk and dawn. They are widespread, and in some areas, they can become overabundant and cause damage to farmland and properties. Protecting natural habitat and fostering an environment where native vegetation can thrive helps create safe areas for them and may keep them away from populated areas. #Nature #Wildlife #Kangaroo #Macropod #Wurundjeri #YarraValley #Victoria
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 20, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone | Until recently, many treasures from King Tutankhamun’s tomb, including this figurine, or shabti, were kept at the cramped Egyptian Museum in Cairo, which opened in 1902. Artifacts long hidden in storage will be displayed at the new Grand Egyptian Museum in Giza, some for the first time.
Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 20, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | Migrating storks gather at Devegeçidi Dam in Diyarbakir, Türkiye. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic. #MuhammedMuheisen #Kayapinar #Türkiye
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 19, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @erintrieb | A women’s rights activist (who is not named for her protection) puts on makeup at her apartment in Kabul. She shares a flat with two other single women, which is viewed as unacceptable in Afghan society. Most landlords in Afghanistan will not rent a home to a single woman.

Though they are relatively few, single women who choose to have female roommates or live alone are often harassed by their neighbors, threatened, or forced to vacate their apartments, accused of being prostitutes. The woman pictured here has since fled Afghanistan, stating she’s received death threats from the Taliban. She hopes to immigrate to the U.S. or Europe but struggles to find visa opportunities. For more stories on Afghanistan follow @erintrieb.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 19, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Danielle Villasana @davillasana | Salt mining in Peru’s Sacred Valley pre-dates Incan civilization. The roughly 4,500 ponds that make up the terraced Maras mines contain salt believed to heal illnesses and ailments. The salt is harvested by local families, an occupation passed down through generations. In order to prevent contamination, tourists are no longer allowed to walk along the salt pans, but they can view the extensive, impressive structures from lookout points. Follow @davillasana for more photos of places throughout Latin America.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 19, 2022.

Go behind the scenes with five Nat Geo Photographers who crisscrossed the world.

Photograph by Kiliii Yüyan, National Geographic
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 18, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @waynelawrence | South African actress Lindiwe Dlamini is renowned in some Broadway circles as the longest-performing cast member of Disney’s The Lion King, which celebrated its 25th anniversary on November 13. Every year, she returns to her Umlazi township in Durban, South Africa to support young artists there alongside her husband, Bongi Dumi, also a longtime cast member of The Lion King and a child of Umlazi. They keep it quiet, but together, the couple helps direct about $100,000 in annual funding from Broadway Cares, a nonprofit that collects money and donates it to her family’s church in Umlazi and other South African arts organizations. They plan to build their own arts center in the nearby rural area to provide young people with even less resources than those in the township access to global opportunities. Read the full story at the link in bio.

(1) Lindiwe sits for a portrait at the Minskoff Theatre in New York City.
(2) Lindiwe during a recent performance of The Lion King.
(3) Lindiwe on the beach near where she grew up.
(4) Members of a cultural troupe pose with Lindiwe after their performance at her family church in Umlazi, South Africa.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 18, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames, words by National Geographic Explorer @paula_kahumbu | Nothing can prepare you for the sight and smell of so many dead wildebeests, zebras, elephants, giraffes, cattle, and sheep that are littering the barren landscape of southern Kenya’s Kajiado County. These catastrophic deaths come after 18 months without rain, the result of three failed rainy seasons. The low rainfall isn’t new, but it is the first time such extreme losses have been recorded. Interacting factors, such as climate change and overstocking of livestock, have made the land far less productive and far more vulnerable to shocks like drought. Though there’s water to drink, there’s not a blade of grass. Rains in the past week have slightly improved conditions, but unless they persist the problem will continue to worsen. With support from the National Geographic Society @insidenatgeo.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 18, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames, words by National Geographic Explorer @paula_kahumbu | Nothing can prepare you for the sight and smell of so many dead wildebeests, zebras, elephants, giraffes, cattle, and sheep that are littering the barren landscape of southern Kenya’s Kajiado County. ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 18, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Cristobal Cespedes Lorenzo, 51, ferries coconuts across the river to his home in Copala, on the coast of Mexico's state of Guerrero. Cristobal and Francisco Manzanares Cagua (in the water), 16, sell their pickings to a company that makes coconut butter and oil.
This image is part of Solar Portraits, my ongoing project focused on the lack of electricity access around the world and the impact of solar power on different communities. Follow me on @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens. #solar #Mexico #solarportraits #solarpanels #solarpower
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 17, 2022.

The uncrewed mission, known as Artemis I, is a critical step in NASA’s campaign to return humans to the moon for the first time in more than 50 years.

Photograph by Dan Winters, National Geographic
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 16, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | Sachatamia ilex is a glass frog with impressive, beautiful eyes. I observed a few individuals during my last visit to the Ecuadorian Chocó. Parental care is rare with this species, as with other glass frogs, and during the night, they can be found in the vegetation close to streams and rivers. Thanks to nonprofits such as @fundacion.jocotoco, this region of Ecuador and the animals that inhabit it have a chance to survive. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to see more weird-looking animals. #ecuador #frog #glassfrog #amphibians
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 16, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @williamodaniels | In a gold mine in the Russian Far East, a leaky pipe created this frozen waterfall of muddy water, dusted with fresh snow. I took this photograph in 2015 for "Train for the Forgotten," a National Geographic story on remote places along the Baikal-Amur Magistral (BAM) railway, which crosses Siberia and the east for more than 4,000 kilometers (2,500 mi). Follow me on @williamodaniels for more stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 15, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | Lorises, like this greater slow loris, are the only existing venomous primate species in the world. Their venom is produced when secretions from a gland on their elbow mix with their saliva, which is then delivered into the bloodstream of their victims by razor-sharp teeth. The potent mixture, a form of protection against parasites and predators, can cause swelling, anaphylactic shock, and in some cases even death. Photo taken @mnzoo. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #loris #slowloris #great #animal #mammal #venomous #primate #nocturnal #vulnerable #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 15, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @amivitale | Lekupania is a Samburu animal whisperer, who cares for a host of species like elephants, gerenuks, kudo, warthogs, and so many more. Here, he reaches up to feed two orphaned giraffes in his care at the Reteti Elephant Sanctuary (@r.e.s.c.u.e). While known for its work with elephants, @r.e.s.c.u.e also helps care for other animals. I'm celebrating Reteti's 6th anniversary with Lekupania and the rest of the team this month. Follow @amivitale to learn more, including how to help. #giraffe #conservation #kenya #africa #babyanimals
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 13, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @iantehphotography | The trip was a grand adventure: a rickety train ride from Hanoi toward Lao Cai, near the China border, then a drive up into the picturesque paddy fields in Sapa, where I met up with farmers for a final trek into cardamom plantations grown under the rainforest canopy. It was also a lesson in Vietnam’s recent environmental history: Black cardamom, thao qua, an essential spice in pho and other Vietnamese dishes, was first planted in the Hoang Lien Mountains in the 1990s as a replacement for opium, a banned crop that once helped prop up Indochina’s colonial economy. The area, known as Hoang Lien National Park, is a symbol of postwar Vietnam’s efforts to protect plant biodiversity. Hence this puzzle: How could a forest simultaneously be a haven for conservation and agricultural cash crop?

Over a few days of camping in the forest, we observe farmers harvesting cherry red pods of raw cardamom with machetes beside a stream. In the afternoons, they smoked the refrigerator-size piles under fire till they turned coffee brown, significantly reducing their weight for the hike back. On our return, we stop at this spot revealing a set of lush green peaks before we dip down into thick vegetation for the remainder of our walk home. Follow me on @iantehphotography to see more images and stories from around the world.
#HoangLienMountains #Vietnam #BlackCardamom
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 13, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @gabrielegalimbertiphoto and Juri de Luca | Fossils of
long-extinct creatures aren’t just for museums—they’re in homes and businesses, as wealthy collectors indulge a controversial hobby. At the Hanging Gardens of Marqueyssac in France, communications officer Stéphanie Angleys cleans the display case of a 150-million-year-old allosaurus. Owned by French businessman Kléber Rossillon, the gardens are open to the public. Rossillon acquired the dinosaur—whose skull is among the best preserved in the world—in 2016, a few years after it was found in Wyoming (U.S.). Follow me @gabrielegalimbertiphoto for more stories. #dinosaur #fossil #extinct #dinosaurskull
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 13, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Corey Arnold @arni_coraldo | Learning to camera-trap wildlife, especially in urban settings, takes a lot of practice and luck. One of the toughest variables is predicting where the animal you are trying to photograph will travel within a frame, and this fence hole in Chicago narrowed my options for success. A parade of animals passed through here every night to access an underpass beneath a busy highway that connected two large green spaces. I was surprised to see one house cat show up almost every night, sometimes minutes before a coyote passed through. One night, while quietly adjusting the camera, I was nearly run over by a coyote running full speed through the hole, not knowing I was there until the last minute. Check out the feature “Why Cities Are Going Wild” in the July issue of National Geographic. @christinedellamore #urbanwildlife #coyote #deer #raccoon
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 12, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @moisessaman | Shadad al Ali, the director of the Dhamar Museum in southwestern Yemen, stands among its ruins. He recalls arriving in the aftermath of the destruction and digging through the rubble with his bare hands. Destroyed in an air strike by the Saudi Arabian-led coalition in May 2015, the museum contained more than 12,000 archaeological objects, representing the history of an ancient center of Arab and Islamic culture.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 12, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | During an expedition to Borneo's Gunung Mulu National Park in 2018, I traveled with a team that spent a week on the banks of the Melinau River, at Camp 5—a small, wooden structure nestled in the gorge between two massifs, Mount Benarat (pictured) and Mount Api. The base offered the team a starting point to access nearby caves, where the scientists had several sampling sites. At the end of each long and tiring day, it was an amazing feeling to relax while gazing up at the white cliffs of limestone—which reveal several cave entrances. I had climbed to them, exploring the maze of passages inside the mountain, on previous expeditions some 10 years ago.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 12, 2022.

Only three weeks old when her father was shot down over Germany, Sharon Estill Taylor devoted decades of detective work to learning his fate.

Photograph courtesy of The National WWII Museum
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 11, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @erintrieb | The years I spent embedded with the U.S. military in Afghanistan are ones I can never forget. Throughout 2009-2011 I embedded for months at a time with both the U.S. Army and Marines. Gunfire and IED (improvised explosive device) attacks occurred daily, often taking life or limb. We collectively knew that every step we took through the Kandahar desert might be our last. Today and every day I remember the brave young service members, now veterans, who allowed me to document their most harrowing and intimate moments in war.
These images were taken in October 2010, in Kandahar Province's Zhari District.

Image 1: Sgt. Andrew Collins (center) and Sgt Dustin Hennigar of the 101st Airborne Division take a cigarette break. 2: Marine K-9 handler Zachary Miller, left, attached to the 502nd Infantry Regiment of the 101st Airborne Division, settles down for the night in an abandoned compound during Operation Clarksville.
Images 3 and 4: 101st Airborne soldiers at dawn before a mission, and resting while on a foot patrol. 5: PFC Matthew Sharpe, 19 (Alpha Company, 2nd Battalion/502nd Infantry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division), receives medical treatment after two IEDs exploded during Operation Clarksville. 6: Military medics aid PFC James Thorne, 19, was injured after stepping on a pressure plate IED. Final: A chinook takes flight as soldiers from the 2-502 Infantry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division prepare a dawn mission.

Follow me @erintrieb for more stories on the U.S. military in Afghanistan.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 11, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @lynseyaddario | Drought, conflict, instability, and rising prices are creating unprecedented levels of food insecurity and looming famine across various countries in the Horn of Africa.

(1) Fatuma Yassin, 34, embraces her severely malnourished three-month-old son, Khalid, in the Gardo Hospital in Puntland, Somalia. Yassin and her four children had depended on pastoralist relatives to provide meat and milk from the animals, but as the ongoing drought persisted, these relatives moved away in search of food and water. (2) Women displaced by drought seek help at the Gabo Gabo camp about 15 miles (24 km) from Jijiga, the capital city of the Somali region in Ethiopia, in May 2021. (3) Twenty-eight-year-old Şahan Omer Jibrin, a mother of eight children, has been living in a camp for three months. She had to flee her home in Ula Ula, Ethiopia, to seek aid because of the drought. (4) A grave humanitarian crisis is unfolding in Ethiopia, which is struggling with a vicious civil war in the north and devastating climate-change effects in the south. Prolonged drought has wiped out livestock, driven displacement, and altered families’ ability to make a living. (5) Sadio Abdi Rahman Ahmed, 50, stands with three of her six children near their tent at a camp in Baidoa, Somalia. From left to right are Faiso, age eight; Abdi Haffid, three; and Ahalan, five.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 10, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @lynseyaddario | Drought, conflict, instability, and rising prices are creating unprecedented levels of food insecurity and looming famine across various countries in the Horn of Africa.

(1) Fatuma Yassin, 34, embraces her severely malnourished three-month-old son, Khalid, in the Gardo Hospital in Puntland, Somalia. Yassin and her four children had depended on pastoralist relatives to provide meat and milk from the animals, but as the ongoing drought persisted, these relatives moved away in search of food and water. (2) Women displaced by drought seek help at the Gabo Gabo camp about 15 miles (24 km) from Jijiga, the capital city of the Somali region in Ethiopia, in May 2021. (3) Twenty-eight-year-old Şahan Omer Jibrin, a mother of eight children, has been living in a camp for three months. She had to flee her home in Ula Ula, Ethiopia, to seek aid because of the drought. (4) A grave humanitarian crisis is unfolding in Ethiopia, which is struggling with a vicious civil war in the north and devastating climate-change effects in the south. Prolonged drought has wiped out livestock, driven displacement, and altered families’ ability to make a living. (5) Sadio Abdi Rahman Ahmed, 50, stands with three of her six children near their tent at a camp in Baidoa, Somalia. From left to right are Faiso, age eight; Abdi Haffid, three; and Ahalan, five.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 10, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | No, this is not a scene from "Alien vs. Predator." It's a scorpion (Tityus sp.) feeding on a small centipede. I captured the image at night in the Ecuadorian Chocó, a protected forest. Follow @javier_aznar_photography and @fundacion.jocotoco to learn more. #scorpion #ecuador #centipede #predation
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 10, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @nataliekeyssar | Victor de la Cruz, originally from the Dominican Republic, has lived in New York City for 40 years and worked as a cook. He poses for a portrait in Queens Plaza at a photo booth created for a National Geographic story on the borough of Queens, one of the most diverse and vibrant communities in the world where over 300 languages are spoken.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 10, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @andreabruce | In the article on “keepers of community” in the September issue of National Geographic magazine, read about Missy Nester, the publisher of the Welch News, and her small staff in West Virginia. They are part of the glue that holds their community together.

It’s just after 1 p.m. on Wednesday, May 8, 2019, when the printing press kicks on. You might expect the mechanical behemoth to surge to life with a trembling roar, or at least a deep, low growl, but for the first half minute, this Goss Suburban newspaper press is silent. Soon the gears swell into a loud zipping that alerts the staff, standing in anticipation, to the first copy’s emergence. A machine of this nature, though imposing in size and gritty in appearance, is remarkably delicate and has taken an entire morning of gentle detailing—greasing, inking, brushing, wiping—before it’s ready to run a clean, consistent print. It is a process that requires a great deal of care.

Spending time with the staff at the Welch News, it becomes clear that devotion to care begins at the printing press before bleeding out like runaway ink into the community it serves, finally coming to rest contentedly in the homes of its roughly 3,000 subscribers in West Virginia’s Appalachia.

It had been one year since Melissa “Missy” Nester had placed a bid to purchase the last remaining local newspaper in McDowell County.

“We’re the only news source in the poorest county in West Virginia and—being that we’re the poorest county—media sources that surround us come in to tell only the negative stories of our county,” Nester says. “It’s really important for us to tell the positive stories about our county and encourage our community.”

This project exists with support from @catchlight.io, @photowings, @nationalwritingproject, and the amazing @lorraineustar. Read the full story at the link in bio. #onassignment
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on November 09, 2022.
